What is impressive is the wealth of evidence presented and the manner in which they are analyzed. The environmental approach to history can run the risk of the "comprehensive syndrome," i.e., too detailed and sweeping and long, that it sometimes reads like a chore. I read it on and off for almost a year. It was like attending a course in ecology. On the strength of this book, I'd likely attend more lectures by Prof. Diamond through his other books.

I had many "whoa" moments while reading this book. I had never realized that corn took so long to travel from the highlands of current Mexico to areas of the current USA. Once I got Diamond's point that many Eurasian epidemics have their roots in the diseases that strike domesticated animals of Eurasia I definitely smacked my own forehead. Wow. Using comparative linguistics to determine which people ate which plant or animal first is amazing. Food production, geography, environmental factors, domesticable animals, natural resources -- all of these things have greatly influenced the ebb and flow power from one region's peoples to another, and back again. Race, however, has not been a determinative factor. It is important to read books like this today when various groups express racist narratives about entire nations of people -- "They don't send their best people" or "shithole countries."Diamond's sense of humor and humility are steady currents underlying the entire book. He prefaces some sections with statements like, "This chart will horrify academic experts in this field. . . but I generalize for a reason." The story about the bedside interpreting at a hospital gone wrong is not one to be forgotten (hysterical!).I highly recommend this book.

The one sentence to summarize this book is "history followed different courses for different people because of differences of the environment, not of biological differences among people themselves." The logic behind is fairly straightforward - weather/ landscape affects wild plants/ animals availability for domestication which in turn affects the chance of food production and thus gems, technology, writing and eventually politics. Therefore, the reason you were born in a developed country and are more educated and wealthier is because your ancestors were lucky enough to be born in certain part of the world, NOT because your are smarter nor your gene is better than the rest of the world.I like the way how the author elaborates his logic. He uses tons of historical examples plus archeology discoveries - a perfect marriage between history and science. Although the empire of climate can only explain first half of the world history (probably until the time of medieval as the courses of modern history are far too complex to be explained only by environmental factors), this book has already provided answers to many many questions.

Diamond's synthesis argues for geography not as the sole decider in human affairs but certainly as the main one. Any work of this sweep is going to have holes in its particulars, but Diamond is overall very persuasive. Yet, there is one serious failing that I detected: his discussion of technology. Diamond wants to reject the racial explanation for why whites came to dominate the world. In this he is right, but he goes too far. European technological superiority came in the main from the scientific revolution. This in large part explains why Europe became the center of world power. While Diamond is right that geography formed the basis for that revolution, there was something deeper happening in Europe that allowed for the swiftest technological revolution in history. And while the "Great Man" view of history is certainly false, it has its uses. Diamond, at least in his thoughtful conclusion acknowledges that. It is the great strength of the book; he makes a good argument but is no brute reductionist. Nuance is welcome.Last thing: the pictures in the book are the most bafflingly useless I have ever seen in a major work.

I am glad I picked up this book. If only I could throw hardbound copies of this book (weight: 2.1 lbs) at the faces of people going around distorting history. It presents a fascinating take on the evolution of human societies and manages to answer very fundamental and difficult questions in a clear and objective manner through the combined lens of geography, biology, linguistics and economics. One of the biggest statement the book makes is to show how strongly environmental quirks outside their control affect the trajectories of the societies living in it. I expected the book to be quite similar to Sapiens by Yuval Harari but they are very different books. I remember Yuval being a lot more personal with his narrative. Also, Jared is a lot more detailed in his materialistic comparison of different societies. I would have liked more information on how the Indian Subcontinent was populated. It does not find much mention. But stating that is not to deny the wealth of information that this book already offers.Published in 1997, it is 20 years old today but still highly recommended!

As a scientific book it fails overall.Pro:Diamond seems very sympathetic towards all people and cultures. He also knows a lot about different ways the societies collect food and in what environment they live in. Things he probably has learned from studying birds.Con:This is how not to do science. Most of his great conclusions are loosely based on the findings he picks out to support his ready made conclusions. Nothing is proved or disproved in any way in this book. And he completely ignores genetics and biology even though he talks about people who have adapted to different environments. Sure one group can have been adapted to an environment where there were fewer things to plant and fewer animals to tame. But how did that influence people's genetics? Because it must have done. Everything does. Where do we stand? This book was boring and not informative. It's basically a collection of facts mixed in with random opinions/assumptions. But I still like him and he seems sympathetic as a person.

In this book, the author sets out to determine why it is that Eurasians seem to have developed all the technology, and why they've managed to spread and "take over" world-wide, whereas other cultures weren't able to or just didn't do that.It was o.k. I listened to the abridged audio (I hadn't realized it was abridged until I checked it out of the library, but decided to give it a shot, anyway). I'm not sure if some of the stuff that I think I missed (phrases that "suddenly" appeared without a definition, etc) was because I was not paying attention momentarily, or if it was something that was cut out of the book for the abridgment. I don't know if it would have made a difference if the version I had was unabridged, but the book was only o.k. for me. Somewhat interesting, but probably nothing I'll remember for any amount of time. I will probably still try another book by Diamond, however.

4.5 stars. I've wanted to read this since college, when we had to read a few excerpts from it in one of my history classes. I remember them making a big impression on me, so I put it on my to-read list... Fifteen years later, I did it! And I really liked it! Well organized, well explained, I felt like I learned so much, AND I want to keep learning more about human history and geography. In fact, now I wonder if I should've studied archaeology? Is it too late? Man, it gave me so much to think about. Half a point off because sometimes I felt like it was a little too repetitive on certain points.

Another successful book club joint!First, you have to admire the audacity of the author - I'm going to summarise as much as I can of human history (and pre-history) in 500 pages, and I'm going to do it with a background in ornithology and linguistics! Then, you have to admire that he somehow successfully drew it all together.The book is dense with information, all there to bolster his argument that geography matters a ton (or as summarised at book club, life is about shit dumb luck).I really liked the study of Polynesia as a microcosm of his theory.If there were crtitiques it'd be that it gets a bit repetitive by the end, and that he's so focussed on his theory he maybe doesn't consider other aspects of humanity (in that sense Sapiens makes an excellent companion volume).Definitely worth a future re-read and note-taking.

Hey, he starts off using the Holocene Calendar! :-)Interesting answer to Yali's question of why white folks had so much cargo when black folks had so little, via the Anna Kerrinina principle of interlocking factors: no genetic group is more or less intelligent, on average (shown by years of testing), but population density and farming based on local geographical factors tend to determine the technologies which are developed following the animals, mineral and vegetable or soil resources. Also taken into account is that germs develop very differently with diffferent population densities, and more food requires more and better storage techniques and leads to development of beauracracy as well as expansionist tendencies which become more aggresssive with higher population density.6 August, 12017 HE(the Holocene Calendar)

When I read Sapiens I felt that I had taken a new journey in human history. Guns, Germs and Steel should've been the start of that journey. If I knew better I would have read this book first and Sapiens after. The two complement each other almost perfectly.Guns, Germs and Steel focuses on the geographic and ecological impact of human development. It was very clear from start that Jared Diamond was fully aware of the limitations of historians to develop the equivalent of a scientific theory and that he made those limitations the strength of this book.I found the last part unnecessary. It functions as the demonstration of the theory, somewhat similar to the predictive properties of a scientific theory but in hindsight. However I felt it added nothing. The epilogue on the other hand is brilliant and fully justifies this last part.

I had thought that this book was another work of historical determinism which justified colonization. I was, however, pleasantly surprised by the author's beautiful analysis using a very well-constructed framework that is highly nuanced and manages to rigorously explain the broad trends of history in simple language. This book is neither deterministic nor does it justify European colonization. The Epilogue is in itself worth reading in order to appreciate the author's wish to develop a historical science that is inter-disciplinary and follows a rigorous methodology based on natural experiments rather than approaching history through preconceived ideological frameworks.
[They were very lucky to have farming, animals and germs.  (hide spoiler)]

I only hate myself for not reading this book oh so many years ago when it shocked the world. This is the kind of uncommon reading of history you simply don't hear. It undermines so many casual racial explanations for the development and 'under-development' of the various parts of the globe. I'd say it's a must read just for the excellent geography lesson in every chapter. But the length it goes to in explaining the domestication of plants and animals over time is wonderful as well. Additionally, the language study is quite informative. Just a book full of marvels.

This book reads like a textbook or a coursebook. I have read 3 books now which are similar in themes. "Why nations fail", " Sapiens:A brief history of humankind" and "Guns,Germs and Steel". Of these 3, Sapiens is more fun. I will highly recommend that one. After reading sapiens, if you want to explore more, GGS is your pick. And if you want to delve more into the politcal aspects of history, "why nations fail" should be in your hand. Nevertheless, it is a good book.

The Freak-anomics before Freak-anomics. But like Freak-anomics, it blurs the line between causal relations and coincindental relations for his conclusions.It was a very interesting read, but as I look back on it now it seems less conclusive and more academic porn of sorts masquerading as academic research. This sentiment is echoed by many others as well.Good book and writing, but the less-than-conclusive conculsions leave much to be desired. That knocks it down to a 2-star

I find it utterly unbelievable that this book gets anything less than five stars. Diamond can't state his elegant case strongly enough. This book changed the way I look at history, and nobody but the most die-hard racists can come away from it without having a thoroughly new outlook on the way the world is. Five stars way up.

This book was three stars all the way through until I started reading the epilogue, which I thought was five stars, then I got to the second half of the epilogue, and it went back down to three. This is a really informative book, albeit a little dry. There is only so much information about corn and wheat that I can process on a given day. Most of the book was that, corn and wheat and cereal and grains and lots of other boring food words, and also a lot of linguistic stuff, which was pretty interesting, and some cool things about diseases (basically the reason you have such a kickass immune system is because your granddaddy's granddaddy's granddaddy slept with horses), but almost nothing about guns, which was what I was hoping to read. There is LOTS of repeating in this book, LOTS AND LOTS, and I think the epilogue (the first half, anyway) tells you much more succinctly what the first 400 or so pages said. And the book still barely answers the primary questions it started out with, mainly why has the whole world pretty much been run by Europeans (or Americans) for the last 500 years. Oddly, the book takes you right up until 500 years ago, then kind of runs out of steam right when it would be getting interesting. In the epilogue he timidly, slowly begins to touch on what to me seems really obvious, i.e. culture, but I guess in academia that's something you have to tip toe around. It's not at all hip or kosher to slam someone's culture, but culture has tons and tons to do with why and how a country functions the way it does. Give a certain group of people all the benefits in the world, but when corruption is accepted as a necessary part of society, when rabid nationalism and worship of anyone older than you is seen as the only way to not be an asshole, and when any new idea is seen as ridiculous strictly because it's new, you're going to have problems. Another thing that kind of irked me about this book was the continual use of putting certain phrases in quotation marks, like the "discovery" of the New World. Yeah, dork, I get it, no one really "discovered" the New World after 10,000 years ago, but I'm not a 10 year old brainwashed student, I get it. Another funny thing was he kept calling it a racist viewpoint to hold that white Europeans were so powerful because of a genetic superiority (and I would also think it's kind of racist), but then he turns around and says, in his opinion, New Guineans are on average more intelligent than Europeans. Typical guilty white liberal. So it's racist to say Europeans are smarter than other people, but not racist, I guess, to say New Guineans are smarter than other people? This kind of skyscraper-sized inconsistency is what drives me up the fucking wall when reading these kinds of books, and makes me feel there will never be any real progress in the social sciences because everyone's so sensitive about what they should or shouldn't say.

I've known of this book for a long time and have even seen a documentary based on it so I finally took the plunge. I really like the central idea that the environment has shaped human societies (for better or worse) and that there isn't an intrinsic difference between people's of different environements - we're all suited to get the most out of our particular niches. I also understand the cascade effect of domesticating plants and animals. My issue with the book is that Diamond takes a far too deterministic view and makes individuals/groups to be mere passengers in the sweep of environmental history and I think that's too simplistic. While history may play out similarly based on the axis of the Earth I don't think it would play out exactly the same because there are simply too many variables. I did enjoy the discussion on plant and animal domestication though and the link with disease was fascinating. There's another fun snippet of linguistics as a historical tool (which is expanded upon in "the third chimpanzee") and the discussion on geographical barriers is interesting.I didn't enjoy his reductionist view on inventions and the idea they just happen along with the head-scratching claim that most ideas are acquired from other places (but they still have to come from somewhere!). He also has the habit of being a tiny bit apologetic when it comes to western society (in the sense they were lucky as opposed to justifying their actions) which I suspect is a knee-jerk reaction to all the imperialist works suggesting it's because Europeans were better than the "savages" but I think it would have been best to stick with the idea it's the environment that's shaped societies (although it's always going to be difficult to separate a leader's views from their environment). Diamond also skims over religion yet again which I always find frustrating but there is at least a brief discussion of its role in societies and how it can be used as a justification/tool in colonisation.The epilogue is very good at addressing a lot of my issues with some of his claims and convenient omissions throughout the book. The problem is that by that point I was already frustrated with some of the things he'd said (or hadn't) and that jaded my view of most of his claims in the main text. I'd certainly recommend new readers to skip to the epilogue after the introduction before reading the meat of the book as I know I'd have enjoyed it far more knowing he'd taken these other interpretations into consideration.Another fun thought I started to have towards the end of the book was that Yali might have wished he'd never asked Jared the cargo question if he'd had to listen to an 11 hour answer.It's still a great book for getting you to alter the way you look at things and I think it's something fantasy authors should look at when drawing their world maps too (I know I can't help but wonder where their fertile crescents are)!

Are you fond of big history?Did you enjoy reading Sapiens and wish to dig deeper?Have you come to terms with the innate cruelty of humans and want to read a dispassionate analysis of its root causes?Do you also suffer from insomnia because the fundamental questions of our evolution cause you anxiety?Are you that cat which has the potential to get killed by curiosity?If the answer to any of those questions is 'yes', you know what's to be done.

I really enjoyed this... for a while... until grew to dislike this after the first half. I found half the book almost entirely repetition and the latter bit on languages complexly boring and a hassle to follow. Every other page there would be a half page digression restating a dozen things already stated. It was a neat read. BUT I felt empiricism was a bit lacking at times. while much of the book is convincing, much of it is also the authors OWN opinions based on correlations/causations/inference style arguments to justify his ideas, some of which diverge from generally accepted ones. He has a tendency to infer and correlate and then peat himself so much so that by the time I finished the book I was cursing it.I was expecting something vastly different. this entire book is about food production and geographic inhibitions of it, which consequently benefit Eurasia while be disadvantageous to other places such as Australia. It has a very unempirical feel to it. The author himself even mentions people will disagree with his methodology and tries to back it up by calling sciences like Astronomy, historical science rather than actual science. The epilogue made me really dislike the author for his assumptions about some sciences not being sciences like astronomy. He claims you cant test anything and so, basically, he is saying his interred theories should be valid.. because as he sees it, Astronomy isn't scientific in that you cant test it. Just... wow... He also dismissed individual geniuses like Einstein... shrugging them all off... claiming that they were basically just lucky to be the ones that and the final touches on some innovation. The author, thus, comes off as very narcissistic and self absorbed in his own intellect. whether he is or not, I don't know, but the epilogue certainly suggested it.The first half was great. As I got maybe 60-70% through I grew weary and tired of his line of logic. I had hoped this were to be more factual based, than hypothetical. It felt as though I were reading someones PHD thesis by the end. He also has this irritating habit of mixing up the words is and are, making some sentences read oddly.I may seem vexed and I am. This book could have been a fraction of the size it was. I felt cheated by being forced to read so much repetition (yup, i am repeating this complaint again). I may not have picked this book up had I known what lie past the half way mark. Alas, I hate to leave a book unfinished, and it was interesting at times. I feel as though good chunks must be taken with a grain of salt. There are facts thrown in here and there however, I was expecting more of an actual history of civilizations/empires themselves, not so much a discourse on food production. Its an alright book at points, but could be better.

Guns, Germs, and Steel (GGS) is an illuminating and sweeping panorama of human history. It is thought-provoking, logical, and debunks racist theories by highlighting the undeniable significance of geographic and climatic influences on the developments and progressions of human societies. For example, civilization and technology spread fastest throughout the Eurasian continent partly due its vast width and its east-west latitudinal axis, which allows for a fairly consistent temperate climate and a quicker spread of food production. Food production leads to societal/political organization and specialization of labor. This yields more leisure time to the educated elites, allowing them to cogitate, innovate, and develop world-changing technologies like gunpowder, the printing press, and the steam engine. The second largest continents, Africa and the Americas are narrower in width and have a north-south axis. This makes it more difficult for food production and peoples to spread since they have to transgress climatic hurdles (certain foods only grow at certain elevations and latitudes) such as the Sahara Desert and the Isthmus of Panama. Secondly, Africa and the Americas had fewer native, domesticable animals. Eurasia had horses, dogs, goats, cows, and sheep while North America and Africa had the less effective camels, llamas, and alpacas. Horses aided Eurasians in warfare, dogs in hunting, and goats, cows, and sheep on the farm in food production. You might be wondering- what about the vast animal diversity in Africa? Well, Africa’s zebra (the horse’s closest equivalent) is finicky, fearful, unaccommodating, and to this day has still not been domesticated. We all know how the various feline species (lions, tigers, leopards, etc.) are less submissive than dogs and therefore less domesticable. In its title GGS explains how the proximate factors of guns, germs, and steel enabled Europeans to first sail to the Americas and conquer the Native Americans and not the other way around. The ultimate factors that explain why the Europeans first came to possess guns, germs, and steel are due to their head start in food production and availability and use of domesticable animals (from which they derived many of the germs that would later wipe out the Native Americans). Eurasia also had more diverse plants available to begin and sustain food production. This book is a beast to get through (especially when reading about plants), but the sense of satisfaction and illumination obtained after conquering the beast and becoming more understanding of why societies developed at different rates is well worth it. Well done, Diamond.

I will be the first to say that I am not a huge non-fiction person. However, my eyes were opened to the genre over the summer when I read a phenomenal, fast-paced non-fiction novel for my AP Biology class, The Demon in the Freezer. This was no Demon in the Freezer.For starters, barely 30 pages into the book, the first red flag popped up. Jared Diamond is not a historian. Nor is he an anthropologist. Rather, he is an evolutionary biologist. So, okay. There's a slight connection. But still, I felt that it called into question his expertise on the topic. I found Diamond's writing to be terribly dry. Granted, history is, to me, not exactly the world's most exciting topic, but surely it could have been less bland. Maybe a joke or two? A pun? Something to keep the reader engaged? I didn't care much about the vast majority of the topics. Only a few really interested me, which I acknowledged was not the book's fault. But it was mighty difficult to trudge through each boring chapter. My only salvation was that each chapter was broken up into little mini passages, so I could give myself rewards for finishing a single passage. You think I'm kidding? Ask Alex.Another thing that saved this book from a DNF? The pictures. They were frequent enough for me to look forward to them and get excited whenever one popped up. It meant I didn't have to read a page! But the one strange thing about the pictures was that there were two twenty-page (each!) sections of the book that were simply photographic portraits of different people. There was not even a single mention of these photographs until the epilogue of the book, so I was like "what is going on" whenever one of these sections popped up literally in the middle of a sentence.The final gripe I have with the book was one section of a chapter in which Diamond did not write anything. Well, he quoted. He quoted for an entire chapter. Basically, it went down like this:"so, the invasion of the Incas by the Spanish was pretty bad but I don't really feel like explaining it to you, so here's a couple primary sources"Thanks??? The only reason this book deserves two stars is that at least some of the content is interesting. And, I must admit that I did learn something at the end, which is the point of a non-fiction novel.Overall, this just wasn't the book for me. It was terribly dense, bland, and boring, and had me watching the page count like a hawk, just waiting for page 431 to pop up.

This book is full of interesting ideas. What it is not full of is citations. Actually, there are NO citations. No footnotes, no endnotes, just the dreaded "further reading" sections in the back. Am I the only one that hates that? I doubt it.As I began reading I was flagging pages I had questions about. So many pages were flagged a gave up. This would be a GREAT book for discussion--in class, or in a book group. Me? I am arguing with myself and looking things up on Wikipedia. Not ideal.So...Diamond never defines "agriculture" or "domestication" to my satisfaction. Nor (obviously) does he give a source for a standard archeological or anthropological definition of either. Yet I kept wondering, through the entire book, where he was drawing lines. Native Australian canals for eel raising/harvesting is not domestication, not is it agriculture. So what is it? How does it not "count"? I know the author has studied a lot in New Guinea. He talks about it. A lot. Yet India is virtually invisible in this book (except for the Chinese, Austronesians, and Europeans that traded there). Why? Why not a tidbit about Japan?Anything else you ask? Why yes. The author's tone is somewhat condescending, there is too much first person for my taste ("I think it is obvious" "When I was in New Guinea"), too many determinedly wobbly statements (such as "make this inference virtually certain" (348) and "I would guess" (349)), and way way WAY too much speculation ("What if Hitler had died in 1930?" "What if the Inca had..." what if what if what if). There are also many statements like "Protein starvation is probably also the ultimate reason why cannibalism was widespread in traditional New Guinea highland societies." (p149). Really? Citation(s)? Please pretty please? That's a huge statement to stick a "probably" in the middle of, with no backup.So...what do I think? I don't know what to think. The book is interesting, if annoying. But without citations I really can't form a true opinion. I don't think Diamond has invented a new discipline "Historical Science" as he seems to think he has (epilogue). I would argue this book isn't a history book at all, it's geography, or anthropology. It's historical, yes, but it's not history.And I think it's a bit of a ripoff of Alfred Crosby. Whom Diamond mentions, but I don't think he gives him the credit he deserves.
A new smart, enlighting and fun facts source fave of mine.

One of those books you wonder how you missed. Getting on for 20 years old now but its basic thesis - that geography not genes is the determining factor as to why the Old World dominates the New - still struck me as clear, thoughtful and powerfully argued. The detail and complexity of what Diamond had to say was both compelling and surprisingly readable; I read every one of the 440 pages and a few of the endnotes to boot. One small quibble: in the 2003 afterward, Diamond discusses some of the implications raised by his final reflection in regards to the organisation of groups of people and the role of leadership in history. Specifically, he discusses conversations with the likes of Bill Gates about how best to organise teams in business. Whilst the conclusions of these reflections may be reasonable (they seemed so to me), they seemed to miss what I take to be the main point of the book: it is the geographical circumstances of humanities history which has been most clearly deterministic rather than specific human cultural or behavioural characteristics. The corollary of this observation in business would seem to me to have much more to do with the kind of industry and its location than with the behaviour of CEOs and employees. I would have thought Diamond's considerable insights might be more powerfully directed towards reflecting on where, when and how industries are located and the consequent implications for their success. This kind of reflection seems to me to fit more appropriately with the "scientific" approach he so consciously devotes to his approach in the bulk of "Guns, Germs, and Steel".Regardless, this is a powerful, brilliant book which has shaped and coloured my thinking and filled in some important holes in my understanding of the parts of the world where I live. I'm off to write a post on my blog about the Boonwurrung, the people whose culture and land my ancestors destroyed with their guns, germs and steel.

Full disclosure: I am writing this in one unpremeditated, unedited go, mostly on the adrenaline of deep frustration.It is baffling to me how dismissive—almost disdainful—Diamond is of the Chinese writing system throughout, with a level of unqualified criticism uncharacteristic of the rest of the book. “For example,” Diamond writes, “the prestige value of Chinese culture is still so great in Japan and Korea that Japan has no thought of discarding its Chinese-derived writing system despite its drawbacks for representing Japanese speech, while Korea is only now replacing its clumsy Chinese-derived writing with its wonderful indigenous hangul alphabet.” Is this what so-called objective “scientific writing” looks like? I don’t know who Diamond’s supposed Japanese and Korean friends are (he cites these nebulous figures once, with the affectation of one claiming “My black friends don’t ask me to say African-American”), but as a native Chinese speaker who did not learn the language through Diamond’s expressly preferred, Latin alphabet-based pinyin, as well as a Japanese speaker, I call Massive Bullshit on his unfounded, unprofessional condemnation.This is compounded with an additional 2003 chapter on Japan and Korea whose “guys, you’re ‘twin brothers,’ why don’t you make peace for the progress of humanity” policy recommendation I found condescending.I understand that these only make up a small percentage of what is an ambitious, expansive, painstakingly detailed cross-disciplinary work, but it was enough to deeply bother and distract at least one reader. I also find that, in the wake of Yuval Noah Harari’s bestsellers and the rise of scholarly podcasts, Diamond’s fact-dumping narrative voice is startlingly humorless, sometimes to the point of somnambulant. Having been told for almost a decade that this is a seminal work I must read to understand the world, this fell short of expectations—to say the least.

I was less astounded by “Guns, Germs and Steel” than I might otherwise have been, partly due to the success of the book. Diamonds ideas are simple and persuasive. I’m sure that when they were first expounded in the 1997 that they created quite a stir. In the past two decades they have become part of the mainstream. I’m not sure when or where, but somehow I’ve heard almost all his arguments before. They’re part of my psyche. Reading Diamond’s book was less of a revelation for me and more like learning the details of something I already know.“Guns Germs and Steel” is about as thrilling as a book full of facts can be. It’s like attending a very interesting anthropology lecture; it’s work, but fun work. There were some moments when I zoned out a little. I felt that Diamond provided too many examples, but this complaint probably relates to what I said earlier. I came to this book already informed of Diamond’s thesis and halfway convinced. This made all the arguments somewhat superfluous for me.It’s a very intellectually satisfying book. Any mildly empathetic person will look at the inequities of the world feel frustrated. We want an answer that explains why terrible things happen to innocent people. Some find the answer in religion and the unknowable nature of God. If that isn’t a good enough answer for you, Diamond’s book will help fill in the gaps. He draws lines from climate and geography to colonialism, providing, if not a solution, at least and explanation for all the pain in the third world. I’m not saying that his arguments are 100% correct, but they will make you feel a little closer to finding order in a chaotic world.

Jared Diamond’s Pulitzer Prize winning book about how and why civilization emerged the way they did was very introspective and engaging. He is a biologist who lived in New Guinea. He came to appreciate the native people there and one in particular, Yani asked him why westerners had so much relative to the natives on New Guinea. He explored the reasons for why civilizations emerged as they did.Diamond describes the evolution of agriculture and written language in an interesting way. His explanation on the advantages of East-West orientation between Europe and Asia over North-South orientations of Africa and the Americas helped to explain why some areas dominated over others. Having navigable river systems instead of mountains and deserts helped spread the domestication of farming and the domestication of animals. Therefore, the emergence of farming flourished more in some areas, Eurasia, over others. All animals in nature could not be domesticated and used for farming like some of the big animals in Africa.Guns were a force in dominating some societies and the materials necessary are not found everywhere on our planet. He discussed the impact of germs, the immunity defense developed by urban dwellers, and the harm caused to these urban dwellers who came in contact with the people who lacked these immunities. Steel was used for the making of weaponry and machinery so became prominent in later years. Diamonds explanations were cohesive and understandable. It is essential reading for anyone interested in reading how civilizations emerged.

I finally finished this classical anthropology book, which has been sitting on my TBR in last 5 years. It took me weeks to read, as I moved forward/backward a lot to get a better understanding and to become familiar with the details. Guns, Germs and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies is the macro history of human societies. This book is based on solid research and written as a text book--an introduction followed by well-organized chapters, each chapter contains detailed descriptions, a conclusion that summarizes the main points made in the book, ended with an epilogue where future enhancements and competing theories are briefly discussed.Geographical environment, including flora and fauna, shaped the early development of human societies. Its ripple effect is still felt today. There are lot of great, very interesting points. One of them is the comparison between the three regions of the old world: The Fertile Crescent, Europe and China. Was The Fertile Crescent the first region in the world where the environment made inhabitable by the inhabitants? China's early unity, a result of its environment, shaped China into a technological and social advanced country. However, from 15th century onwards, the same unity became a negative force and caused China to lag behind.Again, the book is the macro history, the board sketches of the past 11000 years of human life, not the micro history or the role of random events in the course of history. A full 5-star non-fiction.

Amusing to read the slew of negative reviews in Amazon. It's hardly surprising though, given the subject matter of the book and its revolutionary approach to the interpretation of history. Prof. Diamond presents his case well that I think some of the debated quotes in the reviews were taken out of context, or were taken as absolutes. I can imagine why some arguments are controversial. They're not always "politically correct" and often run against conventional knowledge. Prof. Diamond is talking about the origin of "races," why some are more affluent than others and why some are not destined to prosper. His central argument is quite basic: environment, not race, is the main determinant of success of societies. Very humane and obvious but still debatable. What is impressive is the wealth of evidence presented and the manner in which they are analyzed. The environmental approach to history can run the risk of the "comprehensive syndrome," i.e., too detailed and sweeping and long, that it sometimes reads like a chore. I read it on and off for almost a year. It was like attending a course in ecology. On the strength of this book, I'd likely attend more lectures by Prof. Diamond through his other books.

I had many "whoa" moments while reading this book. I had never realized that corn took so long to travel from the highlands of current Mexico to areas of the current USA. Once I got Diamond's point that many Eurasian epidemics have their roots in the diseases that strike domesticated animals of Eurasia I definitely smacked my own forehead. Wow. Using comparative linguistics to determine which people ate which plant or animal first is amazing. Food production, geography, environmental factors, domesticable animals, natural resources -- all of these things have greatly influenced the ebb and flow power from one region's peoples to another, and back again. Race, however, has not been a determinative factor. It is important to read books like this today when various groups express racist narratives about entire nations of people -- "They don't send their best people" or "shithole countries."Diamond's sense of humor and humility are steady currents underlying the entire book. He prefaces some sections with statements like, "This chart will horrify academic experts in this field. . . but I generalize for a reason." The story about the bedside interpreting at a hospital gone wrong is not one to be forgotten (hysterical!).I highly recommend this book.

The one sentence to summarize this book is "history followed different courses for different people because of differences of the environment, not of biological differences among people themselves." The logic behind is fairly straightforward - weather/ landscape affects wild plants/ animals availability for domestication which in turn affects the chance of food production and thus gems, technology, writing and eventually politics. Therefore, the reason you were born in a developed country and are more educated and wealthier is because your ancestors were lucky enough to be born in certain part of the world, NOT because your are smarter nor your gene is better than the rest of the world.I like the way how the author elaborates his logic. He uses tons of historical examples plus archeology discoveries - a perfect marriage between history and science. Although the empire of climate can only explain first half of the world history (probably until the time of medieval as the courses of modern history are far too complex to be explained only by environmental factors), this book has already provided answers to many many questions.

Diamond's synthesis argues for geography not as the sole decider in human affairs but certainly as the main one. Any work of this sweep is going to have holes in its particulars, but Diamond is overall very persuasive. Yet, there is one serious failing that I detected: his discussion of technology. Diamond wants to reject the racial explanation for why whites came to dominate the world. In this he is right, but he goes too far. European technological superiority came in the main from the scientific revolution. This in large part explains why Europe became the center of world power. While Diamond is right that geography formed the basis for that revolution, there was something deeper happening in Europe that allowed for the swiftest technological revolution in history. And while the "Great Man" view of history is certainly false, it has its uses. Diamond, at least in his thoughtful conclusion acknowledges that. It is the great strength of the book; he makes a good argument but is no brute reductionist. Nuance is welcome.Last thing: the pictures in the book are the most bafflingly useless I have ever seen in a major work.

I am glad I picked up this book. If only I could throw hardbound copies of this book (weight: 2.1 lbs) at the faces of people going around distorting history. It presents a fascinating take on the evolution of human societies and manages to answer very fundamental and difficult questions in a clear and objective manner through the combined lens of geography, biology, linguistics and economics. One of the biggest statement the book makes is to show how strongly environmental quirks outside their control affect the trajectories of the societies living in it. I expected the book to be quite similar to Sapiens by Yuval Harari but they are very different books. I remember Yuval being a lot more personal with his narrative. Also, Jared is a lot more detailed in his materialistic comparison of different societies. I would have liked more information on how the Indian Subcontinent was populated. It does not find much mention. But stating that is not to deny the wealth of information that this book already offers.Published in 1997, it is 20 years old today but still highly recommended!

As a scientific book it fails overall.Pro:Diamond seems very sympathetic towards all people and cultures. He also knows a lot about different ways the societies collect food and in what environment they live in. Things he probably has learned from studying birds.Con:This is how not to do science. Most of his great conclusions are loosely based on the findings he picks out to support his ready made conclusions. Nothing is proved or disproved in any way in this book. And he completely ignores genetics and biology even though he talks about people who have adapted to different environments. Sure one group can have been adapted to an environment where there were fewer things to plant and fewer animals to tame. But how did that influence people's genetics? Because it must have done. Everything does. Where do we stand? This book was boring and not informative. It's basically a collection of facts mixed in with random opinions/assumptions. But I still like him and he seems sympathetic as a person.

In this book, the author sets out to determine why it is that Eurasians seem to have developed all the technology, and why they've managed to spread and "take over" world-wide, whereas other cultures weren't able to or just didn't do that.It was o.k. I listened to the abridged audio (I hadn't realized it was abridged until I checked it out of the library, but decided to give it a shot, anyway). I'm not sure if some of the stuff that I think I missed (phrases that "suddenly" appeared without a definition, etc) was because I was not paying attention momentarily, or if it was something that was cut out of the book for the abridgment. I don't know if it would have made a difference if the version I had was unabridged, but the book was only o.k. for me. Somewhat interesting, but probably nothing I'll remember for any amount of time. I will probably still try another book by Diamond, however.

4.5 stars. I've wanted to read this since college, when we had to read a few excerpts from it in one of my history classes. I remember them making a big impression on me, so I put it on my to-read list... Fifteen years later, I did it! And I really liked it! Well organized, well explained, I felt like I learned so much, AND I want to keep learning more about human history and geography. In fact, now I wonder if I should've studied archaeology? Is it too late? Man, it gave me so much to think about. Half a point off because sometimes I felt like it was a little too repetitive on certain points.

Another successful book club joint!First, you have to admire the audacity of the author - I'm going to summarise as much as I can of human history (and pre-history) in 500 pages, and I'm going to do it with a background in ornithology and linguistics! Then, you have to admire that he somehow successfully drew it all together.The book is dense with information, all there to bolster his argument that geography matters a ton (or as summarised at book club, life is about shit dumb luck).I really liked the study of Polynesia as a microcosm of his theory.If there were crtitiques it'd be that it gets a bit repetitive by the end, and that he's so focussed on his theory he maybe doesn't consider other aspects of humanity (in that sense Sapiens makes an excellent companion volume).Definitely worth a future re-read and note-taking.

Hey, he starts off using the Holocene Calendar! :-)Interesting answer to Yali's question of why white folks had so much cargo when black folks had so little, via the Anna Kerrinina principle of interlocking factors: no genetic group is more or less intelligent, on average (shown by years of testing), but population density and farming based on local geographical factors tend to determine the technologies which are developed following the animals, mineral and vegetable or soil resources. Also taken into account is that germs develop very differently with diffferent population densities, and more food requires more and better storage techniques and leads to development of beauracracy as well as expansionist tendencies which become more aggresssive with higher population density.6 August, 12017 HE(the Holocene Calendar)

When I read Sapiens I felt that I had taken a new journey in human history. Guns, Germs and Steel should've been the start of that journey. If I knew better I would have read this book first and Sapiens after. The two complement each other almost perfectly.Guns, Germs and Steel focuses on the geographic and ecological impact of human development. It was very clear from start that Jared Diamond was fully aware of the limitations of historians to develop the equivalent of a scientific theory and that he made those limitations the strength of this book.I found the last part unnecessary. It functions as the demonstration of the theory, somewhat similar to the predictive properties of a scientific theory but in hindsight. However I felt it added nothing. The epilogue on the other hand is brilliant and fully justifies this last part.

I had thought that this book was another work of historical determinism which justified colonization. I was, however, pleasantly surprised by the author's beautiful analysis using a very well-constructed framework that is highly nuanced and manages to rigorously explain the broad trends of history in simple language. This book is neither deterministic nor does it justify European colonization. The Epilogue is in itself worth reading in order to appreciate the author's wish to develop a historical science that is inter-disciplinary and follows a rigorous methodology based on natural experiments rather than approaching history through preconceived ideological frameworks.
[They were very lucky to have farming, animals and germs.  (hide spoiler)]

I only hate myself for not reading this book oh so many years ago when it shocked the world. This is the kind of uncommon reading of history you simply don't hear. It undermines so many casual racial explanations for the development and 'under-development' of the various parts of the globe. I'd say it's a must read just for the excellent geography lesson in every chapter. But the length it goes to in explaining the domestication of plants and animals over time is wonderful as well. Additionally, the language study is quite informative. Just a book full of marvels.

This book reads like a textbook or a coursebook. I have read 3 books now which are similar in themes. "Why nations fail", " Sapiens:A brief history of humankind" and "Guns,Germs and Steel". Of these 3, Sapiens is more fun. I will highly recommend that one. After reading sapiens, if you want to explore more, GGS is your pick. And if you want to delve more into the politcal aspects of history, "why nations fail" should be in your hand. Nevertheless, it is a good book.

The Freak-anomics before Freak-anomics. But like Freak-anomics, it blurs the line between causal relations and coincindental relations for his conclusions.It was a very interesting read, but as I look back on it now it seems less conclusive and more academic porn of sorts masquerading as academic research. This sentiment is echoed by many others as well.Good book and writing, but the less-than-conclusive conculsions leave much to be desired. That knocks it down to a 2-star

I find it utterly unbelievable that this book gets anything less than five stars. Diamond can't state his elegant case strongly enough. This book changed the way I look at history, and nobody but the most die-hard racists can come away from it without having a thoroughly new outlook on the way the world is. Five stars way up.

This book was three stars all the way through until I started reading the epilogue, which I thought was five stars, then I got to the second half of the epilogue, and it went back down to three. This is a really informative book, albeit a little dry. There is only so much information about corn and wheat that I can process on a given day. Most of the book was that, corn and wheat and cereal and grains and lots of other boring food words, and also a lot of linguistic stuff, which was pretty interesting, and some cool things about diseases (basically the reason you have such a kickass immune system is because your granddaddy's granddaddy's granddaddy slept with horses), but almost nothing about guns, which was what I was hoping to read. There is LOTS of repeating in this book, LOTS AND LOTS, and I think the epilogue (the first half, anyway) tells you much more succinctly what the first 400 or so pages said. And the book still barely answers the primary questions it started out with, mainly why has the whole world pretty much been run by Europeans (or Americans) for the last 500 years. Oddly, the book takes you right up until 500 years ago, then kind of runs out of steam right when it would be getting interesting. In the epilogue he timidly, slowly begins to touch on what to me seems really obvious, i.e. culture, but I guess in academia that's something you have to tip toe around. It's not at all hip or kosher to slam someone's culture, but culture has tons and tons to do with why and how a country functions the way it does. Give a certain group of people all the benefits in the world, but when corruption is accepted as a necessary part of society, when rabid nationalism and worship of anyone older than you is seen as the only way to not be an asshole, and when any new idea is seen as ridiculous strictly because it's new, you're going to have problems. Another thing that kind of irked me about this book was the continual use of putting certain phrases in quotation marks, like the "discovery" of the New World. Yeah, dork, I get it, no one really "discovered" the New World after 10,000 years ago, but I'm not a 10 year old brainwashed student, I get it. Another funny thing was he kept calling it a racist viewpoint to hold that white Europeans were so powerful because of a genetic superiority (and I would also think it's kind of racist), but then he turns around and says, in his opinion, New Guineans are on average more intelligent than Europeans. Typical guilty white liberal. So it's racist to say Europeans are smarter than other people, but not racist, I guess, to say New Guineans are smarter than other people? This kind of skyscraper-sized inconsistency is what drives me up the fucking wall when reading these kinds of books, and makes me feel there will never be any real progress in the social sciences because everyone's so sensitive about what they should or shouldn't say.

I've known of this book for a long time and have even seen a documentary based on it so I finally took the plunge. I really like the central idea that the environment has shaped human societies (for better or worse) and that there isn't an intrinsic difference between people's of different environements - we're all suited to get the most out of our particular niches. I also understand the cascade effect of domesticating plants and animals. My issue with the book is that Diamond takes a far too deterministic view and makes individuals/groups to be mere passengers in the sweep of environmental history and I think that's too simplistic. While history may play out similarly based on the axis of the Earth I don't think it would play out exactly the same because there are simply too many variables. I did enjoy the discussion on plant and animal domestication though and the link with disease was fascinating. There's another fun snippet of linguistics as a historical tool (which is expanded upon in "the third chimpanzee") and the discussion on geographical barriers is interesting.I didn't enjoy his reductionist view on inventions and the idea they just happen along with the head-scratching claim that most ideas are acquired from other places (but they still have to come from somewhere!). He also has the habit of being a tiny bit apologetic when it comes to western society (in the sense they were lucky as opposed to justifying their actions) which I suspect is a knee-jerk reaction to all the imperialist works suggesting it's because Europeans were better than the "savages" but I think it would have been best to stick with the idea it's the environment that's shaped societies (although it's always going to be difficult to separate a leader's views from their environment). Diamond also skims over religion yet again which I always find frustrating but there is at least a brief discussion of its role in societies and how it can be used as a justification/tool in colonisation.The epilogue is very good at addressing a lot of my issues with some of his claims and convenient omissions throughout the book. The problem is that by that point I was already frustrated with some of the things he'd said (or hadn't) and that jaded my view of most of his claims in the main text. I'd certainly recommend new readers to skip to the epilogue after the introduction before reading the meat of the book as I know I'd have enjoyed it far more knowing he'd taken these other interpretations into consideration.Another fun thought I started to have towards the end of the book was that Yali might have wished he'd never asked Jared the cargo question if he'd had to listen to an 11 hour answer.It's still a great book for getting you to alter the way you look at things and I think it's something fantasy authors should look at when drawing their world maps too (I know I can't help but wonder where their fertile crescents are)!

Are you fond of big history?Did you enjoy reading Sapiens and wish to dig deeper?Have you come to terms with the innate cruelty of humans and want to read a dispassionate analysis of its root causes?Do you also suffer from insomnia because the fundamental questions of our evolution cause you anxiety?Are you that cat which has the potential to get killed by curiosity?If the answer to any of those questions is 'yes', you know what's to be done.

I really enjoyed this... for a while... until grew to dislike this after the first half. I found half the book almost entirely repetition and the latter bit on languages complexly boring and a hassle to follow. Every other page there would be a half page digression restating a dozen things already stated. It was a neat read. BUT I felt empiricism was a bit lacking at times. while much of the book is convincing, much of it is also the authors OWN opinions based on correlations/causations/inference style arguments to justify his ideas, some of which diverge from generally accepted ones. He has a tendency to infer and correlate and then peat himself so much so that by the time I finished the book I was cursing it.I was expecting something vastly different. this entire book is about food production and geographic inhibitions of it, which consequently benefit Eurasia while be disadvantageous to other places such as Australia. It has a very unempirical feel to it. The author himself even mentions people will disagree with his methodology and tries to back it up by calling sciences like Astronomy, historical science rather than actual science. The epilogue made me really dislike the author for his assumptions about some sciences not being sciences like astronomy. He claims you cant test anything and so, basically, he is saying his interred theories should be valid.. because as he sees it, Astronomy isn't scientific in that you cant test it. Just... wow... He also dismissed individual geniuses like Einstein... shrugging them all off... claiming that they were basically just lucky to be the ones that and the final touches on some innovation. The author, thus, comes off as very narcissistic and self absorbed in his own intellect. whether he is or not, I don't know, but the epilogue certainly suggested it.The first half was great. As I got maybe 60-70% through I grew weary and tired of his line of logic. I had hoped this were to be more factual based, than hypothetical. It felt as though I were reading someones PHD thesis by the end. He also has this irritating habit of mixing up the words is and are, making some sentences read oddly.I may seem vexed and I am. This book could have been a fraction of the size it was. I felt cheated by being forced to read so much repetition (yup, i am repeating this complaint again). I may not have picked this book up had I known what lie past the half way mark. Alas, I hate to leave a book unfinished, and it was interesting at times. I feel as though good chunks must be taken with a grain of salt. There are facts thrown in here and there however, I was expecting more of an actual history of civilizations/empires themselves, not so much a discourse on food production. Its an alright book at points, but could be better.

Guns, Germs, and Steel (GGS) is an illuminating and sweeping panorama of human history. It is thought-provoking, logical, and debunks racist theories by highlighting the undeniable significance of geographic and climatic influences on the developments and progressions of human societies. For example, civilization and technology spread fastest throughout the Eurasian continent partly due its vast width and its east-west latitudinal axis, which allows for a fairly consistent temperate climate and a quicker spread of food production. Food production leads to societal/political organization and specialization of labor. This yields more leisure time to the educated elites, allowing them to cogitate, innovate, and develop world-changing technologies like gunpowder, the printing press, and the steam engine. The second largest continents, Africa and the Americas are narrower in width and have a north-south axis. This makes it more difficult for food production and peoples to spread since they have to transgress climatic hurdles (certain foods only grow at certain elevations and latitudes) such as the Sahara Desert and the Isthmus of Panama. Secondly, Africa and the Americas had fewer native, domesticable animals. Eurasia had horses, dogs, goats, cows, and sheep while North America and Africa had the less effective camels, llamas, and alpacas. Horses aided Eurasians in warfare, dogs in hunting, and goats, cows, and sheep on the farm in food production. You might be wondering- what about the vast animal diversity in Africa? Well, Africa’s zebra (the horse’s closest equivalent) is finicky, fearful, unaccommodating, and to this day has still not been domesticated. We all know how the various feline species (lions, tigers, leopards, etc.) are less submissive than dogs and therefore less domesticable. In its title GGS explains how the proximate factors of guns, germs, and steel enabled Europeans to first sail to the Americas and conquer the Native Americans and not the other way around. The ultimate factors that explain why the Europeans first came to possess guns, germs, and steel are due to their head start in food production and availability and use of domesticable animals (from which they derived many of the germs that would later wipe out the Native Americans). Eurasia also had more diverse plants available to begin and sustain food production. This book is a beast to get through (especially when reading about plants), but the sense of satisfaction and illumination obtained after conquering the beast and becoming more understanding of why societies developed at different rates is well worth it. Well done, Diamond.

I will be the first to say that I am not a huge non-fiction person. However, my eyes were opened to the genre over the summer when I read a phenomenal, fast-paced non-fiction novel for my AP Biology class, The Demon in the Freezer. This was no Demon in the Freezer.For starters, barely 30 pages into the book, the first red flag popped up. Jared Diamond is not a historian. Nor is he an anthropologist. Rather, he is an evolutionary biologist. So, okay. There's a slight connection. But still, I felt that it called into question his expertise on the topic. I found Diamond's writing to be terribly dry. Granted, history is, to me, not exactly the world's most exciting topic, but surely it could have been less bland. Maybe a joke or two? A pun? Something to keep the reader engaged? I didn't care much about the vast majority of the topics. Only a few really interested me, which I acknowledged was not the book's fault. But it was mighty difficult to trudge through each boring chapter. My only salvation was that each chapter was broken up into little mini passages, so I could give myself rewards for finishing a single passage. You think I'm kidding? Ask Alex.Another thing that saved this book from a DNF? The pictures. They were frequent enough for me to look forward to them and get excited whenever one popped up. It meant I didn't have to read a page! But the one strange thing about the pictures was that there were two twenty-page (each!) sections of the book that were simply photographic portraits of different people. There was not even a single mention of these photographs until the epilogue of the book, so I was like "what is going on" whenever one of these sections popped up literally in the middle of a sentence.The final gripe I have with the book was one section of a chapter in which Diamond did not write anything. Well, he quoted. He quoted for an entire chapter. Basically, it went down like this:"so, the invasion of the Incas by the Spanish was pretty bad but I don't really feel like explaining it to you, so here's a couple primary sources"Thanks??? The only reason this book deserves two stars is that at least some of the content is interesting. And, I must admit that I did learn something at the end, which is the point of a non-fiction novel.Overall, this just wasn't the book for me. It was terribly dense, bland, and boring, and had me watching the page count like a hawk, just waiting for page 431 to pop up.

This book is full of interesting ideas. What it is not full of is citations. Actually, there are NO citations. No footnotes, no endnotes, just the dreaded "further reading" sections in the back. Am I the only one that hates that? I doubt it.As I began reading I was flagging pages I had questions about. So many pages were flagged a gave up. This would be a GREAT book for discussion--in class, or in a book group. Me? I am arguing with myself and looking things up on Wikipedia. Not ideal.So...Diamond never defines "agriculture" or "domestication" to my satisfaction. Nor (obviously) does he give a source for a standard archeological or anthropological definition of either. Yet I kept wondering, through the entire book, where he was drawing lines. Native Australian canals for eel raising/harvesting is not domestication, not is it agriculture. So what is it? How does it not "count"? I know the author has studied a lot in New Guinea. He talks about it. A lot. Yet India is virtually invisible in this book (except for the Chinese, Austronesians, and Europeans that traded there). Why? Why not a tidbit about Japan?Anything else you ask? Why yes. The author's tone is somewhat condescending, there is too much first person for my taste ("I think it is obvious" "When I was in New Guinea"), too many determinedly wobbly statements (such as "make this inference virtually certain" (348) and "I would guess" (349)), and way way WAY too much speculation ("What if Hitler had died in 1930?" "What if the Inca had..." what if what if what if). There are also many statements like "Protein starvation is probably also the ultimate reason why cannibalism was widespread in traditional New Guinea highland societies." (p149). Really? Citation(s)? Please pretty please? That's a huge statement to stick a "probably" in the middle of, with no backup.So...what do I think? I don't know what to think. The book is interesting, if annoying. But without citations I really can't form a true opinion. I don't think Diamond has invented a new discipline "Historical Science" as he seems to think he has (epilogue). I would argue this book isn't a history book at all, it's geography, or anthropology. It's historical, yes, but it's not history.And I think it's a bit of a ripoff of Alfred Crosby. Whom Diamond mentions, but I don't think he gives him the credit he deserves.
A new smart, enlighting and fun facts source fave of mine.

One of those books you wonder how you missed. Getting on for 20 years old now but its basic thesis - that geography not genes is the determining factor as to why the Old World dominates the New - still struck me as clear, thoughtful and powerfully argued. The detail and complexity of what Diamond had to say was both compelling and surprisingly readable; I read every one of the 440 pages and a few of the endnotes to boot. One small quibble: in the 2003 afterward, Diamond discusses some of the implications raised by his final reflection in regards to the organisation of groups of people and the role of leadership in history. Specifically, he discusses conversations with the likes of Bill Gates about how best to organise teams in business. Whilst the conclusions of these reflections may be reasonable (they seemed so to me), they seemed to miss what I take to be the main point of the book: it is the geographical circumstances of humanities history which has been most clearly deterministic rather than specific human cultural or behavioural characteristics. The corollary of this observation in business would seem to me to have much more to do with the kind of industry and its location than with the behaviour of CEOs and employees. I would have thought Diamond's considerable insights might be more powerfully directed towards reflecting on where, when and how industries are located and the consequent implications for their success. This kind of reflection seems to me to fit more appropriately with the "scientific" approach he so consciously devotes to his approach in the bulk of "Guns, Germs, and Steel".Regardless, this is a powerful, brilliant book which has shaped and coloured my thinking and filled in some important holes in my understanding of the parts of the world where I live. I'm off to write a post on my blog about the Boonwurrung, the people whose culture and land my ancestors destroyed with their guns, germs and steel.

Full disclosure: I am writing this in one unpremeditated, unedited go, mostly on the adrenaline of deep frustration.It is baffling to me how dismissive—almost disdainful—Diamond is of the Chinese writing system throughout, with a level of unqualified criticism uncharacteristic of the rest of the book. “For example,” Diamond writes, “the prestige value of Chinese culture is still so great in Japan and Korea that Japan has no thought of discarding its Chinese-derived writing system despite its drawbacks for representing Japanese speech, while Korea is only now replacing its clumsy Chinese-derived writing with its wonderful indigenous hangul alphabet.” Is this what so-called objective “scientific writing” looks like? I don’t know who Diamond’s supposed Japanese and Korean friends are (he cites these nebulous figures once, with the affectation of one claiming “My black friends don’t ask me to say African-American”), but as a native Chinese speaker who did not learn the language through Diamond’s expressly preferred, Latin alphabet-based pinyin, as well as a Japanese speaker, I call Massive Bullshit on his unfounded, unprofessional condemnation.This is compounded with an additional 2003 chapter on Japan and Korea whose “guys, you’re ‘twin brothers,’ why don’t you make peace for the progress of humanity” policy recommendation I found condescending.I understand that these only make up a small percentage of what is an ambitious, expansive, painstakingly detailed cross-disciplinary work, but it was enough to deeply bother and distract at least one reader. I also find that, in the wake of Yuval Noah Harari’s bestsellers and the rise of scholarly podcasts, Diamond’s fact-dumping narrative voice is startlingly humorless, sometimes to the point of somnambulant. Having been told for almost a decade that this is a seminal work I must read to understand the world, this fell short of expectations—to say the least.

I was less astounded by “Guns, Germs and Steel” than I might otherwise have been, partly due to the success of the book. Diamonds ideas are simple and persuasive. I’m sure that when they were first expounded in the 1997 that they created quite a stir. In the past two decades they have become part of the mainstream. I’m not sure when or where, but somehow I’ve heard almost all his arguments before. They’re part of my psyche. Reading Diamond’s book was less of a revelation for me and more like learning the details of something I already know.“Guns Germs and Steel” is about as thrilling as a book full of facts can be. It’s like attending a very interesting anthropology lecture; it’s work, but fun work. There were some moments when I zoned out a little. I felt that Diamond provided too many examples, but this complaint probably relates to what I said earlier. I came to this book already informed of Diamond’s thesis and halfway convinced. This made all the arguments somewhat superfluous for me.It’s a very intellectually satisfying book. Any mildly empathetic person will look at the inequities of the world feel frustrated. We want an answer that explains why terrible things happen to innocent people. Some find the answer in religion and the unknowable nature of God. If that isn’t a good enough answer for you, Diamond’s book will help fill in the gaps. He draws lines from climate and geography to colonialism, providing, if not a solution, at least and explanation for all the pain in the third world. I’m not saying that his arguments are 100% correct, but they will make you feel a little closer to finding order in a chaotic world.

Jared Diamond’s Pulitzer Prize winning book about how and why civilization emerged the way they did was very introspective and engaging. He is a biologist who lived in New Guinea. He came to appreciate the native people there and one in particular, Yani asked him why westerners had so much relative to the natives on New Guinea. He explored the reasons for why civilizations emerged as they did.Diamond describes the evolution of agriculture and written language in an interesting way. His explanation on the advantages of East-West orientation between Europe and Asia over North-South orientations of Africa and the Americas helped to explain why some areas dominated over others. Having navigable river systems instead of mountains and deserts helped spread the domestication of farming and the domestication of animals. Therefore, the emergence of farming flourished more in some areas, Eurasia, over others. All animals in nature could not be domesticated and used for farming like some of the big animals in Africa.Guns were a force in dominating some societies and the materials necessary are not found everywhere on our planet. He discussed the impact of germs, the immunity defense developed by urban dwellers, and the harm caused to these urban dwellers who came in contact with the people who lacked these immunities. Steel was used for the making of weaponry and machinery so became prominent in later years. Diamonds explanations were cohesive and understandable. It is essential reading for anyone interested in reading how civilizations emerged.

I finally finished this classical anthropology book, which has been sitting on my TBR in last 5 years. It took me weeks to read, as I moved forward/backward a lot to get a better understanding and to become familiar with the details. Guns, Germs and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies is the macro history of human societies. This book is based on solid research and written as a text book--an introduction followed by well-organized chapters, each chapter contains detailed descriptions, a conclusion that summarizes the main points made in the book, ended with an epilogue where future enhancements and competing theories are briefly discussed.Geographical environment, including flora and fauna, shaped the early development of human societies. Its ripple effect is still felt today. There are lot of great, very interesting points. One of them is the comparison between the three regions of the old world: The Fertile Crescent, Europe and China. Was The Fertile Crescent the first region in the world where the environment made inhabitable by the inhabitants? China's early unity, a result of its environment, shaped China into a technological and social advanced country. However, from 15th century onwards, the same unity became a negative force and caused China to lag behind.Again, the book is the macro history, the board sketches of the past 11000 years of human life, not the micro history or the role of random events in the course of history. A full 5-star non-fiction.

Amusing to read the slew of negative reviews in Amazon. It's hardly surprising though, given the subject matter of the book and its revolutionary approach to the interpretation of history. Prof. Diamond presents his case well that I think some of the debated quotes in the reviews were taken out of context, or were taken as absolutes. I can imagine why some arguments are controversial. They're not always "politically correct" and often run against conventional knowledge. Prof. Diamond is talking about the origin of "races," why some are more affluent than others and why some are not destined to prosper. His central argument is quite basic: environment, not race, is the main determinant of success of societies. Very humane and obvious but still debatable. What is impressive is the wealth of evidence presented and the manner in which they are analyzed. The environmental approach to history can run the risk of the "comprehensive syndrome," i.e., too detailed and sweeping and long, that it sometimes reads like a chore. I read it on and off for almost a year. It was like attending a course in ecology. On the strength of this book, I'd likely attend more lectures by Prof. Diamond through his other books.

I had many "whoa" moments while reading this book. I had never realized that corn took so long to travel from the highlands of current Mexico to areas of the current USA. Once I got Diamond's point that many Eurasian epidemics have their roots in the diseases that strike domesticated animals of Eurasia I definitely smacked my own forehead. Wow. Using comparative linguistics to determine which people ate which plant or animal first is amazing. Food production, geography, environmental factors, domesticable animals, natural resources -- all of these things have greatly influenced the ebb and flow power from one region's peoples to another, and back again. Race, however, has not been a determinative factor. It is important to read books like this today when various groups express racist narratives about entire nations of people -- "They don't send their best people" or "shithole countries."Diamond's sense of humor and humility are steady currents underlying the entire book. He prefaces some sections with statements like, "This chart will horrify academic experts in this field. . . but I generalize for a reason." The story about the bedside interpreting at a hospital gone wrong is not one to be forgotten (hysterical!).I highly recommend this book.

The one sentence to summarize this book is "history followed different courses for different people because of differences of the environment, not of biological differences among people themselves." The logic behind is fairly straightforward - weather/ landscape affects wild plants/ animals availability for domestication which in turn affects the chance of food production and thus gems, technology, writing and eventually politics. Therefore, the reason you were born in a developed country and are more educated and wealthier is because your ancestors were lucky enough to be born in certain part of the world, NOT because your are smarter nor your gene is better than the rest of the world.I like the way how the author elaborates his logic. He uses tons of historical examples plus archeology discoveries - a perfect marriage between history and science.
