The average reader will delight in the simplicity of the book, and how the concepts are explained in great detail without excessive jargon. Jared goes over the rise and fall of civilizations, the modern day players, the development of technologies, and every anthropological factor that might possibly hold a clue. He treats this question as a giant puzzle, and gently assembles the pieces together to make the outline of a picture. Moreover, he himself admits that this is merely the outline of the picture, and the gaps need to be filled in by other writers, and more knowledge. That makes the book endearing, because the author understands the scope of the project, and acknowledges his own limitations. The writing style is somewhat verbose, and would benefit from some hack-n-slash editing, but overall, it remains an excellent book for most readers. Part 2.Unfortunately, I'm not one of those readers. Time to rant a bit. WHYY is the book so slow? I understand that he's trying to not be racist, but treading on eggshells all the way through the book, giving multiple explanations and scenarios to justify the same theory becomes taxing. Frustratingly enough, I understand the need to do that. It took one book, Madison's 'Passing of the Races', to inspire a man like Hitler into committing genocide, so this is probably a topic to tread carefully around. That doesn't make the argument style ANY less annoying. The explanations are drawn out and EVERY single detail is highlighted. With a background in Biotechnology and a strong interest in related sciences, I find his overexplanation of the subject terribly draining in many places. Furthermore, there are a few flaws in the argument, which I will discuss once a few other people have finished reading the book, and I've had a solid discussion with them. In simple terms, a normal scientific book will usually explain a concept at the start of the book, and for the rest of the book, will assume that you know the concept, so as to not double back on explanations. Not Mr. Diamond, noooo. I agree that this book should be made mandatory for anyone with a racist temperament, and their intelligence likely requires the repeated explanations but most people don't. I would happily recommend this book to an average person, but I would think ten times before recommending it to any of my friends because they are likely to get bored and abandon it halfway.More discussion on the flaws in theory is yet to come.

Why did Europe succeed?27 December 2012	This is one of those books that tries to ask the question of why the European civilisation managed to succeed where all other world civilisations failed. His conclusions are interesting, however we must remember that even now, fifteen years after this book was completed we are seeing an economic collapse in the west against an economic resurgence in China, India, and Brazil.	One of the ideas that he had was due to the axis of the continents. The only continent on a horizontal axis is the Eurasian mega-continent, which means that the entire continent is located in the temperate zone. However I find that idea to be a little dubious. Okay, granted, major civilisations arose across the continent: Europe, Arabia, India, and China; and trade existed among these four civilisations, however it does not really account for the rise of Europe to the exclusion of the rest.	One interesting idea I would suggest is to do with the Mongol hordes that smashed across Asia and the Middle East. In a way the Middle East never recovered from those invasions, and China was knocked back hundreds of years. Europe, by pure chance, managed to be spared, which meant that they were able to continue to develop ahead of the other Eurasian powers. This also resulted in them developing shipping which enabled them to take control of the Arabian Sea from the Arabs (since the land routes had been subsequently blocked by the Mongols).	The idea of trade along a horizontal axis is interesting, and we note that there was not much trade between the civilisations of America. Even then simple trade is unlikely to be hindered by tropical conditions. One thing about the American tribes is that they never developed shipping, which would have been something that prevented them from trading over long distances. In Africa we don't see much in the way of trade either, and the closer you get to the equator, the less developed the nations you encounter.	The concept of germs is interesting in that disease is a barrier to development. With malaria in the tropics it makes development of civilisation there difficult at best, and this can also prove a hindrance to trade, and Malaria is a disease that does not thrive well in colder climates. We also note that the common cold wrecked havoc in the Americas, where as the only disease we inherited from the New World was chlamydia, which is a sexually transmitted disease (the common cold is airbourne). However, that does not mean that Europe had been spared its devastating diseases, as the black plague ran rampant for over five hundred years and accounted for the death of up to a third of the population at its height.	Guns and steel deal more with technological development. The Eurasian civilisations had steel and guns were imported from China, but some suggest that the Chinese never used gunpower for weapons. That is rubbish. The Chinese had developed and were using explosives and rockets in warfare, but that did not save them from the Mongol Hordes. Even then, guns were a pretty poor weapon up until the eighteenth century, and were still quite inadequate. It wasn't until the 20th century that their truly devastating power comes into play.	The the balkanised nature of the European states also has a part to play. There is a point in that because there are all these competing countries all trying to gain an advantage over the other, which results in a perpetual arms race. That did not happen in China because the Chinese government pretty much controlled the entire region. However, that does not account for the fact that such balkanisation existed in the Americas and Africa. This also existed to an extent in the Middle East and India, but both of these regions, for a long time, have been under the dominant power of a single empire (the Ottomans in the Middle East and the Mogols, and later the British, in India). 	To me, the only real answer to this is that not only was Europe spared the ravaging of the Mongol hordes, but that we Europeans are in reality a sadistic and savage lot who are always looking for faster and more sophisticated ways of killing each other. It is not that the Native Americans lived in peace, they didn't, it was just that they were satisfied with using basic weapons. Even when they did have access to guns, they took them and then turned them on each other.

The title “Guns, Germs and Steel” invokes in one’s mind the image of clacking metals and blazing guns. Then you suddenly realize you forgot about the germs part because you had no idea how to work gooey pathogens into such an awesome visual. In retrospect, however, you feel like Germs should have been the focal point of this title. Upon further musings, you reject that notion too and want to settle for something more mundane like “A brief history of post-Pleistocene humanity”. Maybe a more riveting title would have driven sales in the upward direction, but the central question that this book sets out to answer is no cakewalk: “Why did history take such divergent trajectories in the different continents?” Why indeed?Different variants of the same question have been posed for quite some time: “Why did Africa fail to launch a single civilization in the past 10,000 years or so?” “Of all the landmasses in the world, why did Eurasia enjoy a such massive headstart in creating giant empires, like the Roman empire in Italy or the Shang Dynasty in China?” “Why did Australian aborigines fail to move beyond the stone age on a timescale of thousands of years whereas the Europeans succeeded in creating and sustaining a modern nation state within two centuries of landing on the western coast of the continent?”Many answers have been proposed and depending on your worldview, you may prefer one over several others. In the pre-Renaissance era, the view of most people pondering over such matters can be summarized in a simple sentence: “They are filthy savages, we are civilized humans. That’s it” With the advent of biological evolution, efforts were made to recast the answer in more scientific terms: “Just as the Cro-Magnons were an evolutionary upgrade on the Neanderthals, so are we (Europeans/ Caucasians) a more advanced form of humans vis-à-vis the blacks/aborigines/Indians.” In retrospect, it might sound hilarious, but at that time, serious research works were carried out to show that Africans have a more primitive skull structure akin to the Chimpanzees. And then came Mendel with genetics and it did not take much time for people to weaponize that concept either. The Nazis believed they were a genetically superior race and actively carried out eugenics to optimize favorable hereditary characteristics among their people, despite zero science to back up such a genocidal social policy. To this day, the genetic superiority theory has no shortage of preachers and evangelists. The likes of Sam Harris and Jordan Petersen are going around the globe and brandishing psychologist Charles Murray’s Race-and-Intelligence Bell Curve. The implication is pretty straightforward, “Look mate, even if slavery, segregation, Jim Crow, mass incarceration and the likes did not happen, the African Americans would still be hard-pressed to climb up the social ladder since they are genetically indisposed to do so. Sad!!” The appropriation of scientific concepts by intellectuals of the social science disciplines to justify confounding claims is nothing new. And as I have already stated, each individual would be amenable to a different answer to this question depending on how he/she perceives the world-at-large. So, in the marketplace of ideas, who should we subscribe to? In other words, which discipline or branch of science is best-suited to answer this question? And the answer is: Anthropology. Wild as it may seem at first, you would think the responsibility to answer a question regarding humans should befell the people whose job is to literally study humans.And this is where this book shines brightly. Jared Diamond does a fantastic job of breaking down the geographical, agricultural, political and social forces that propelled different people to very disparate directions. But most importantly, this book stands as a solid buttress to human capital. Given the right tools and right conditions of existence, anyone possesses the mental faculty to do anything they would want to do. No one is genetically incapacitated to be an engineer or a physicist. But if you choose to believe otherwise, that is your prerogative. Just read the book and see if it can challenge, if not alter radically, your worldview.

To a certain extent, I've always wondered why Guns, Germs, and Steel caused such a huge splash. The main premise boils down to 'differences in geography cause differences in societies and their history', which belongs to the club of the blindingly obvious.Of course, the real point of the book is to pin down just which differences are the important ones. This is a cause for much arguement, but Diamond has successfully pulled out the most important ones as applied to history as a whole. This largely turns into a study of what plants and animals were successfully domesticated in early prehistory, and how that turned certain areas into the origin of settled agriculture. That is still fairly basic stuff, but benefits greatly from studying the results from all around the world all at once, and examining just what it takes for something to be capable of being domesticated. (I know there's been some interesting work done on that since this book came out, but I haven't seen it escape scholarly journals in more detail than a National Geographic article.)From there, Diamond points out how plants and animals are generally adapted to a certain climate, and that while it is fairly easy to find different climates going east and west (due to cold mountains, dry deserts, wet coasts, and other accidents of geology), large differences of climate are guaranteed when traveling any real distance north and south. Looking at a map and noting that the Americas and Africa are divided into north-south zones, while Eurasia is oriented east-west, then provides material to show why certain areas needed to work everything out independently, while others were able to borrow everything they needed from elsewhere (before the Age of Exploration, the two situations were probably somewhat even by landmass; the book naturally spends much more time looking at the former).The main thing that makes this book new is actually the 'germs' part of the book. It is only fairly recently that we've really become aware of where most of the deadly diseases we have to deal with come from—other animals. So societies that have and live closely with lots of domesticatible animals get to suffer from deadly epidemics when an occasional virus adapts to a new host (us), and then develop some level of immunity to it. When people who don't have much/anything in the way of domesticated animals run into people who do, they die off as multiple epidemics run through the countryside. This is the other 'new' part—the fact that a lot of Native American population was wiped out by disease is well known, but it's been hard to realize the scale of the disaster. The "Mound Builders" were a disappeared pre-Columbian civilization of the Mississippi valley, and only recently has it been realized it was actually wiped out by European diseases before any Europeans got there to see it.The 'guns' and 'steel' parts of the book are essentially non-existent. They just serve as part of the proximate cause of how Europeans came to dominate the world before turning to look for the ultimate causes back in prehistory. This is where his biases as a biologist who's picked up a fair amount of practical cultural anthropology show. While he does discuss technology, and the fact that the wider the range of where you can get ideas from, the more ideas you will be able to encounter, he doesn't spend any time looking at the basics of physical technology. A basic study of easily available copper, tin, iron, and clay deposits, compared with the areas that were able to develop settled agriculture could explain much that remains mysterious to him.It's decidedly a layman's book, and has the advantage of being aware of more current research than any pre-college textbook. The fairly breezy, non-technical writing is set off by a good number of informative charts and maps and allow him to make his points without miring himself in the minutia that would lose the non-dedicated reader. Just being able to tackle most of pre-history in a single reasonably-sized volume is an impressive feat of summarization, and the most impressive thing about the book.

I'll let David Graeber speak of this book in a small blurb he wrote about Abdullah Öcalan's "Manifesto For a Democratic Civilization I: The Age of Masked Gods and Disguised Kings":"Considering the circumstances under which the book was written, I'd say the achievement here is quite impressive. Abdullah Ocalan seems to have done a better job writing with the extremely limited resources allowed him by his jailers than authors like Francis Fukuyama or Jared Diamond did with access to the world's finest research libraries." — David GraeberThe conditions of which David Graeber speaks are that of being locked up in solitary confinement with 24 hour/day artificial light illuminating his cell. Allowed to have one book at a time, and oftimes no writing instruments. And the book(s) he wrote were communicated to the public via live speach, or in first draft form written hastily as part of his testimony for his trials.So, is Jared Diamond's book that bad that a guy who's locked up in such brutal conditions can do better? Well, not really. It is almost certain that Jared Diamond reveals important factors that went into the emergence and differentiation of variagrated civilization, it's just that his analysis is definitely incomplete by simple virtue of being more materialistic than that of any hardline marxist. There is very few, and ultimately unconvincing, arguments about the formation of institutions, the emergence of cities, and ultimately of nation-states. And almost no mention of any social movement of any kind.True to the title, the red thread woven through the entire analysis of civilization is done by looking at why certain societies had developed guns, germs, and steel the way they have. It presents rather novel ideas for the layperson not versed in the subject. A quick, and woefully incomplete, enumeration being:1) Euroasia had a geographical advantage because it had more indigenous crops that could potentially be domesticated2) The domestication of said plants could spread from the Fertile Crescent where they first emerged more easily because of relatively uniform climate along the longer axis (east-west) of Eurasia. The Americas suffering from the fact that their longest geographical distance was from north-south, thus cross-cutting through extremely different climates3) Eurasia also had more potential animals for domestication (also goes into why some species are better suited than others), thus Eurasians had a very decisive advantage in terms of the diseases that they developed resistance too, since most ones are of animal origin And so on. You get the picture, right? Fairly solid arguments, and worth carefully studying because they can almost immediately shut up racists, euro-centrists, and so on. But do not think that by reading this book you have garnered enough information about early human history to call it quits. It might be enough to show off at certain parties, but in order to actually synthesise new ways forward there's a long list of problems, not even touched upon, by Jared Diamond.

This was an utter bore. In all honesty, the points of this book could be better learned by playing Sid Meier's Civilization series.Mr. Diamond starts with a question (framed by a question from a New Guinean friend as to why white people are materially richer) and comes up with an answer that can be explained in a page or two. Yet, Mr. Diamond devotes over 400 pages to discussing stuff. The book is extremely repetitive, as he keeps reminding the reader of his conclusions in previous chapters, and runs through crop histories for pages on end. Reading the last chapter is enough to obtain an understanding of Guns, Germs, and Steel.Basically, the world is divided into Eurasia on one end, and the Americas, Africa, and Oceana at the other end. Because Eurasia is so big from east to west without insurmountable barriers, it had more mammals and crops capable of domestication, and had a better way of diffusing crop and animal domestication (and, in turn, technology) to other societies in relative climates. By contrast, the rest of the world didn't, since their north-south narrowness creates too many diverse climates for diffusing crops, or they faced too many geographic barriers. This takes 400 pages of explaining, somehow. Without crops and animals, societies in the other parts of the world didn't have huge population jumps, resistance to diseases from animals, or advanced technology. The end.Mr. Diamond admits that he doesn't explain why only Western Eurasia came to dominate the world instead of the other societies in Eurasia, then he proceeds to an explanation for a few pages (that would've been a more interesting topic). To sum up his final theory, Europe was less integrated, but integrated enough to compete with one another technologically. China was too integrated, and Mesopotamia killed their trees and became a desert. Well, golly.

Why did history unfold differently on different continents? In case this question immediately makes you shudder at the thought that you are about to read a racist treatise, you aren't: as you will see, the answers to the question don't involve human racial differences at all. The book's emphasis is on the search for ultimate explanations, and on pushing back the chain of historical causation as far as possible.Science writing just doesn't get any better than this. Everyone should read this book. It explains why some societies advanced more rapidly than others and the differences between the victors and the vanquished. I don't know if Professor Diamond came up with all of these brilliant observations, but he gets credit for writing the best book about them. I have given this book to at least a half dozen of my friends and relatives. You're welcome.After reading a couple of one and two star reviews I’ve noticed that they all seem to point towards some sort of racism in this book. These days unless you aren’t calling someone else a racist then obviously you are a racist. Is that about it? A lot of people said the book was boring or poorly written. I didn’t find that to be true, quite the opposite. I’ve read it twice. The ideas put forth in this book were novel to me and make complete sense. If there is a better way to explain the course of history it’s still waiting for me to find it. The critics never post another work we all should be reading. I learned an awful lot about plant and animal domestication and his theory of how geography played such an important part in human development was brilliant.

As another reviewer has pointed out, the only thing the matter with this book is the title. It should really be called Germs, Agriculture, and Geographical Positioning. I can see why they went with the later but there is precious little discussion of guns or steel anywhere in the book.That being said, a very interesting read. Here is the essential thesis:“History followed different courses for different peoples because of differences among peoples' environments, not because of biological differences among peoples themselves."This book is a great answer to the racist notions that european culture "won" over other cultures because they were superior, either physically or intellectually. The simple fact is that the different climates led to different germs, crops, and domesticated animals. All of these factors led to how easy a society became "civilized." It's as simple as that but a lot of the things Diamond brought up had never occurred to me.This book explains why we don't:- Have Hunting Cheetahs- Eat Lion Burgers- Grow acorns and eat them- Why the new world died from european diseases and not the other way aroundInteresting stuff but not quite the breathtaking game changer it had been built up to be.

In the prologue, Jared Diamond summarizes his book in the sentence: "History followed diferent courses for different peoples because of differences among peoples' environments, not because of biological differences among peoples themselves."He investigates what those differences were and how they became essencial in how, over thousands of years, Eurasia came to be the one that was able to go out and conquer, instead of being conquered. This book provides a good antidote for racist or supremacist theories about the differences in development of different societies and a solid base for refutation of heroic narratives that distort history.Germs, for instance, were one of the major weapons that conquerers had, when they collided with native peoples. In some cases, 90% and more of the invaded were killed by a disease brought by the invading army.Jared Diamond writes about the differences the continents had that made plant and animal domestication initiate and develop at very different speeds. And goes on to show the effect that had on the cultures that arose after food production and domestic animals allowed for bigger populations, and more complex societies.

This intriguing (if somewhat dry) book takes a 30,000-foot view of human history since the rise of agriculture, asking, "What are the ultimate reasons certain societies like Europe ended up conquering the others, instead of vice-versa?"Setting up the question using examples like the Spanish conquest of South America, the author first considers the immediate factors involved, like the titular guns, germs, and steel, but quickly moves past those to the ultimate factors of geography, crop availability and animal domestication in determining the Spanish advantage long before the two societies collided. In many ways, what we end up with is an ambitious "theory" of world history derived from first-principles.Fair warning, the book is heavy on details about the histories of specific crops and so on which gets a bit dull for the casual reader, but if the premise is at all interesting to you, you will come out the other end feeling a lot less mystified about the large-scale course of world history.PS: See CGP Grey's "Americapox: The Missing Plague" video at https://youtu.be/JEYh5WACqEk for a really good summary of the "germs" part of this book.

This book was recommended to me by a friend who likes the books with grand themes. Spanning the period since the beginnings of animal domestication and settled agriculture, it attempts to answer the question as to why particular regions of the globe developed when they did, socio-economically speaking, and why others never developed societies more advanced than hunter-gatherers. Diamond, a professional scientist and amateur historian, adduces a plausible argument based on environmental givens, an hypothesis with a great carrying capacity.This environmentally-deterministic study is counterbalanced by his later work, Collapse, which treats of the matter of the success and failure of human societies. Here social practices, human behaviors, are determinative, but once again in terms of environmental givens.The subtext to both volumes, what I read into them throughout, was an argument against genetic determinism--in other words, against racism.

Jared Diamond illustrates through a combination of history, science, archaeology, and linguistics how "history followed different courses for different peoples because of differences among peoples' environments, not because of biological differences among peoples themselves".A fascinating and logical trip through history, describing why certain civilizations rose and became dominant and others dwindled or stuck with using hunting and gathering. The answer seems to come down to the ability to produce food through agriculture, which in turn allows for greater population density and faster innovation. Diamond acknowledges the influences of elements like politics, culture, and the Great Man theory, but notes how much less impact these had than environmental factors. Admittedly I lost steam on this one because of the repetition of tracing environmental factors through several regions of the world, but the cases presented were interesting and convincing.

I was appalled when reading it. I am appalled when I think of it. The conclusions drawn by this ornithologist about an entirely unrelated field of study are so ridiculous that I cannot believe the average person:1) actually read this book or2) had the ability to think independently or3) was unmotivated by political correctness In essence the author concludes that aboriginal tribes ( who used Stone Age implements 50 years ago) are the most intelligent beings on the planet. Forget Isaac Newton, Mozart, Da Vinci and others. They belonged to societies that perpetrated war. This in a nutshell is the premise of this much lauded book. Really? Seriously? What about wars for independence, freedom from tyrants, or even communism? Was World War II frivolous and unnecessary? I doubt the aboriginals would think so under Hitler's regime. Sorry to those who bought this message hook, line and sinker. This book is a travesty to true intellectual thought.

Very insightful and highly researched. The book tries to encapsulate the history of human societies in the last 13,000 years into 425 pages. As the author says in the beginning, its an impossible task. Hence the focus is very narrow and the author remarks about the unanswered questions in the epilogue. The author builds a very convincing case of how Eurasia became quite different from say, the Americas or Africa in terms of technology and immunity to major diseases in 1500 which enabled them to conquer most parts of the world. But the book doesn't not go into the differences within Eurasia. Hence it is. though very detailed, a good starting point for further readings on human history and the fates of various civilisations..

Some say this is environmentally deterministic. I say read it still. And realize so many things you probably didn't know before. For example, it says if you think that Africans, Native Americans, and Asians/Australo-asians were inferior when Europeans arrived, think again. It was the environment (namely the lack of 'guns, germs and steel´ and why they didn't have those things) that determined their 'development'. Educational to say the least. Read it and see your assumptions exposed. The key component in who develops and who doesn't is domesticable animals and plants. A zebra is as domesticable as a horse? Think again.

This book gives a phenomenal macro-historic view of the developments of the continents and their people. The cultural, environmental, and agricultural context is stellar, and coherent and has shaped my understanding of how the world has been molded in the past 1000s of years. The reason for the lack of a fifth star is that I feel that it was a little overly verbose. This is more about the fact that I may not be the target audience for a book that goes deeper into the weeds than I always care to. This work pays tremendous respect to historic academic practices, but that may not be what the casually interested in history (like me) is always searching for.

I liked this book. It was very interesting in a wikipedia kind of way. It had so much history-type information. The author did his research and this was clearly a labor of love. Some of his theories have been proven incorrect with discoveries since the publication of his book, but still....very well written.I loved the agricultural part of this the most. I am an avid gardener and it is was fun to hear how ancient man did the same kind of experimentation with plants and crops that I find myself doing to feed my family.

We all must read - for pleasure, learning and a host of other reasons. But above all, we must read because some books change the manner in which we think about and see the world.Diamond is undoubtedly one of the foremost intellectuals of our age and has performed the task of a scientific study of human history with great elegance. The most attractive aspects were he rigorous, interdisciplinary approach and the acknowledgements of the limitations of his work in some areas. This is one book that should be made compulsory reading.

I probably never would have come across this if it hadn't been given to me as a gift. After reading it, all I can say is, "Wow!"His synthesis of a bunch of disciplines to theorize on why and how things ended up the way they did is remarkable. I'm in no position to judge the correctness of his work, but he sure gives you a lot to think about. And, amazingly, it's not a dry, boring book. It's written in a very accessible style.

In this book, the author talks about the idea of how the geographic location determines everything. In other words, the differences between societies and societal development arise primarily from geographical causes. The author uses a variety of examples explaining why the geological location is so important with the Spaniards, Native Americans, and a lot more. I would recommend this book to people that enjoys reading about history and humans.

Phew, incredibly interesting subject matter but after 200 pages, this was a complete slog. Diamond is interesting and convincing but this tome was necessarily repetitive. In other words, I understand why it was so repetitive but...it was repetitive. Well written, well researched and thoughtful. Shorter Monica: I was bored. Everyone should read once.3 stars

Pretty much a book about how certain cultures thrive because they have more food than others. If you like books about crop production then go for it! Couldn't get much info for my class out of this one, but still respect the author for his ideas, research, and work. Just not really what I needed or could use.
A masterpiece of science and history. Obligatory to understand how civilisations have evolved.Análise em Português: http://virtual-illusion.blogspot.com/...

3.5 stars. This was a recommendation to me by my younger son. An extremely and thorough look at evolution of man, animals, food and societies. Some parts were more interesting than others but overall a fascinating look at how cultures, societies, customs, and ways of living came about.
Jared Diamond take on the question of why are there undeveloped countries? Is that even a fair question? A very readable book on some complex questions.
Ahhh, I don't think this one is for me. I was seriously annoyed by Mr. Diamond's tone and approach to the subject. Not for me.
“History followed different courses for different peoples because of differences among peoples' environments, not because of biological differences among peoples themselves”

Guns, Germs, and Steel is basically an answer to the question, "If Europeans aren't innately superior, why did they end up running everything for so long?" Or, in the words of a New Guinean given in the beginning of the book:Why is it that you white people developed so much cargo and brought it to New Guinea, but we black people had little cargo of our own?For me, the best metaphor to frame the whole book in is in terms of a game of Civilization. And while I'm sure most anthropologists and ethnologists are even now launching themselves at the screen with their hands reaching for my neck, I'll lay out my case. Civilization IV has a lot of problems as an accurate model of human history and societal interaction (for example, technology as a tree), but it does demonstrate a lot of Diamond's points.For example, locally available resources. In Civilization IV, if you don't have any sulfur, you can't make gunpowder. If you don't have gunpowder, you'll get steamrolled by any civilization who does unless you trade for it--and if you do that, you're at the mercy of the civilization that's providing it for you, and G-d help you if they declare war on you, because you'll lose your ability to make gunpowder units and get stomped.Second, trade. Civilizations that trade technological innovations often advance much faster than a single civilization that tries to turtle up and go Galt (which is my usual strategy...), and it's not unusually to end up behind the tech curve and run into a cavalry vs. tanks situation when expanding out beyond your traditional borders.Third, terrain. Mountains blocking expansion and trade are bad. Starting in the jungle is bad. Lack of natural resources are bad. Small islands are bad. Deserts are bad. All of those make expansion much more difficult and limit your population, which reduces the rate of your technological progress, so you advance slower, have less to trade, and eventually your cavalry gets steamrolled by tanks.There are plenty of points Guns, Germs, and Steel makes that Civilization simply doesn't cover, though, lest you think that playing a video game will provide the same educational experience. For one, disease vectors--a.k.a., why didn't the Europeans get wiped out by super plagues from the Americas? The simple answer is animals. The Eurasian civilizations lived in very close proximity to animals for most of their existence and most of the really serious diseases that affected humans in the past--smallpox, black plague, flu, and so on--were originally animal diseases that made the jump. The cultures in the Americans simply did not have the same range of animals as the Eurasian cultures did, so they had little exposure to animal-borne diseases and hence little resistance to them, and therefore both died in droves and did not inflict a similar fate on Europeans. The popular image of North America as a pristine wilderness is wrong--it wasn't a wilderness, it was a post-apocalyptic wasteland.Though as an interesting note, Diamond points out that when syphillis first appeared, it was a horrific disease that literally caused people's flesh to rot off and killed in months. It mutated shortly after its initially appearance into the insanity-causing, long-term disease we know today, however, and so Europe never experienced The Years of Rice and Salt.(note that whether syphillis actually came from the Americas is still somewhat controversial)Similarly, Civilization doesn't have climate bands, but they were hugely important in world history. Eurasia is oriented east-west, with a similar latitude and climate the whole length, and a contiguous land route to travel along, so it was easy for animals and plants tamed in one place (mostly the Middle East) to spread all along that climactic band to each of those civilizations. In contrast, the Americas are oriented north-south, with desert or mountain barriers in places, and Australia and Oceania have large expanses of water making trade harder and populations smaller in addition to latitude differences. It was difficult to get crops from one place to another, and because it took longer, there was a lower population for a longer time, which reduced the potential for innovation due to a lower possible number of inventors, thus leading to a technological gap which, in combination with the smallpoxalypse, led to the cultural and physical near-extermination of the Native Americans.That part, at least, is familiar to players of Civilization. More food means more people, which means more science and production, which means faster advancement, and it all feeds into each other until you're the ones with tanks stomping everyone else.Okay, enough about Civilization. Anyway, that's Diamond's theory, but there are a few problems with Guns, Germs, and Steel.For one, it is incredibly dry and boring. I often had to force myself to keep reading, and I'd get a few more pages in before I got distracted by something new and interesting. At least twice, I almost fell asleep while I was reading it. There are other reviews mentioning that it took them up to six months to finally finish the entire book, so be warned.Second, there are no footnotes. For a book like this, I'd expect dozens of pages of footnotes meticulously documenting all his assumptions, but that never happens, and it's much to the book's detriment.Third, for a book about why Europeans dominated the world, it's mostly focused on the far past--as Diamond phrases it, on the question I quoted at the beginning of the review. The actual process of domination isn't covered at all except for a brief section about the Spanish conquest of the Aztecs and the Incas.Finally, and most damningly, the section at the end where Diamond talks about China actually serves to lever open the cracks in his argument. Since the fall of the Western Roman Empire, China and the Middle East were far more advanced than Europe was, and they also lie in the same Eurasian climactic band that Diamond proposes gave the civilizations within a competitive advantage. So, why is it that neither of them conquered everyone? Diamond has two explanations for this. For China, he claims that China's more continuous government worked against it, because it was possible for the government to ban sea exploration (as actually happened) and have it stick, whereas in Europe when Columbus was trying to finance a sea expedition, he could move from government to government when each successive one turned him down until he found some suckers to finance him.The problem is...this is a cultural explanation. It's saying that China didn't dominate the world because of cultural factors. And if that happened in China, why couldn't it have happened elsewhere. Did the Spanish beat the Aztecs who outnumbered them 100 to 1 because of their geography allowing them to develop superior technology, or was it because the Aztecs exacted ruinous tribute from their client states, causing their subjects to hate them and attach themselves to the first people who looked likely to overthrow their hated rulers? Did the Middle East fail to conquer the world because of increasing desertification and the movement of productive agriculture north and west, as Diamond states, or was it because the Mongols smashed through the states there, burned Baghdad to the ground, and destroyed the system of irrigation canals dating back to the Sumerians, causing a population collapse that Iraq did not recover from until the 20th century? Japan proved that it was perfectly capable of dominating all its neighbors after its modernization during the Meiji Restoration, so clearly it wasn't geography holding it back. Was it the Edo period's 
sakoku
 policy? Because that's another cultural explanation. Diamond spends the entire book talking about geographic and climactic factors being the main reason for the dominance of civilizations, and then chops his argument's legs off in the last 10 pages. The most obvious explanation is that it's a combination of these factors, but that's not what Guns, Germs, and Steel is about. The entire book is an argument for the primacy of geographical factors in determining why the Europeans came to be dominant over the last 500 years, but there are just too many holes and too few citations in the argument for it to be really effective. It's useful to add to the historiography of the European conquest and displacement of most of the rest of the world, but in no way should it be taken as a definitive text.

Two decades ago a UCLA geography professor named Jared Diamond published Guns, Germs, and Steel: The Fates of Human Societies. Diamond hypothesized that the arc of human history was dramatically shifted by geographic, environmental, biological, and other factors, resulting in the worldwide dominance of the leading industrial powers during the past 500 years. The book won a 1997 Pulitzer Prize and quickly became a New York Times bestseller.Why is economic development so uneven around the world?Diamond posed questions fundamental to the experience of the human race. “Why did wealth and power [among nations] become distributed as they now are, rather than in some other way?” “[W]hy did human development proceed at such different rates on different continents?” “[W]hy were Europeans, rather than Africans or Native Americans, the ones to end up with guns, the nastiest germs, and steel?” In his award-winning book, Diamond posited a “unified synthesis”—a unified field theory of history. Drawing from his wide-ranging knowledge of medicine, evolutionary biology, physiology, linguistics, and anthropology as well as geography, he surveyed the history of the past 13,000 years and identified plausible answers to the questions he had posed. In the process, he wrote what I consider to be the single most illuminating book on the history of the human race.Academic critics howledHowever, academic critics howled shortly after the publication of Guns, Germs, and Steel: They referred to supposed errors in geography and history, which I find largely pointless. For example, geographers complained that Diamond referred to Eurasia as a single continent rather than separately to Asia, North Africa, and Europe. That’s nitpicking, as far as I’m concerned. And many of these “errors” could simply be differences of opinion. Academics are unbearably dogmatic and dismissive of those who reject their pet theories. Some accused him of racism, although he rejected racist explanations early, forcefully, and often. That criticism is not only unsupported by Diamond’s book, it’s insulting to the reader. The most common and far-reaching complaint was that Diamond had succumbed to the heresy of “environmental determinism.” Understandably, Diamond grounded his argument in geographic and environmental factors—but he repeatedly cited numerous other influences as well. Ultimately, of course, everything we humans do, and everything we’ve done in the millions of years since our ancestors first climbed out of the trees, has been environmentally determined. There were complaints that Diamond had overlooked the contrast between temperate and tropical zones (he didn’t) and that he had only explained what happened 500 years ago but not subsequently (untrue). It might appear that at least some of Diamond’s critics never read the book. However, the most aggravating criticism was that he had ignored the motives that led the industrial nations to undertake colonialism and imperialism on a broad scale. Diamond addressed only the means that enabled the colonial powers to dominate, not the reasons why they chose to do so. To my mind, that’s no error. He didn’t pretend to explain colonialism and imperialism, merely to describe how it had become possible.Is it possible that most of these academic critics were simply bitter that Diamond hadn’t cited their own specialized research?The roots of academic criticismThough the critics undoubtedly uncovered a misplaced fact or unwarranted conclusion here and there through the book, the errors were exceedingly minor in the context of Diamond’s expansive hypothesis. It should be clear to any dispassionate reader that the academic reaction stemmed, above all, from narrow-mindedness and jealousy. The world of academia today is atomized. Specialties, sub-specialties, and sub-sub-specialties abound. It’s not unusual for a scholar to build a career on the study of a single obscure question that, when answered, will be of interest to virtually nobody. Interdisciplinary studies are frowned upon in most academic circles. Generalists are regarded as “not serious.” And scholars who write popular books, must less bestsellers, can expect a chilly reception from their peers.A wealth of meaning behind the titleTo understand where the academic critics went wrong, it’s useful to look at what Diamond signified by his title, Guns, Germs, and Steel. Early in his book, he dwells on the confrontation between the Spanish conquistador Francisco Pizarro and the Inca god-king Atahuallpa. “The immediate reasons for Pizarro’s success included military technology based on guns, steel weapons [such as swords and daggers], and horses; infectious diseases endemic in Eurasia; European maritime technology; the centralized political organization of European states; and writing. The title of this book will serve as shorthand for those proximate factors.”Diamond’s argument in a nutshellIn a Prologue, Diamond poses the question at the heart of this book. He quotes a friend in what is now Papua New Guinea from a conversation in 1972, when he was studying bird evolution there: “‘Why is it that you white people developed so much cargo [goods] and brought it to New Guinea, but we black people had little cargo of our own?'” To answer the question, Diamond begins his story around the year 11,000 BCE, when the last Ice Age was drawing to a close and human beings were beginning to form villages in a few places around the world. It’s unclear whether the formation of villages preceded the deliberate cultivation and production of food, or vice versa. However, regardless of the sequence, that shift from hunter-gatherer society to agriculturally based settlements set in motion the course of events that have led to the “civilization” in which we live.Diamond argues, convincingly, that the much greater availability of domesticable plants and large animals in Eurasia than in sub-Saharan Africa and the Americas. Furthermore, he explains that the east-west orientation of Eurasia from the Bering Strait to the Atlantic Ocean made it possible for the development of agriculture and animal husbandry to spread quickly to distant lands. By contrast, the north-south orientation of the Americas and sub-Saharan Africa—and the presence of barriers such as the Sahara Desert, the Panamanian Isthmus, and the deserts of northern Mexico and southwestern United States—impeded the spread of these (and, later, other) new technologies to the extremities of those continents. The advent of food production enabled the development of ever-larger settlements. This, in turn, spelled the emergence of labor specialization and eventually the growth of empires as well as the appearance and spread of communicable diseases contracted from domesticated animals. Those differences in historical development eventually led to the “guns, germs, and steel” that made Eurasian dominance possible—and dictated the huge differences in economic development between what today we call East and West.Guns, Germs, and Steel is crammed with facts and densely written. It doesn’t make for light reading. But if you have any interest in understanding how the world came to be as it is, you’ll find this book highly rewarding.

In a cultural climate where avowed white supremacists regularly make headlines and elected officials can claim with a straight face that people of color have contributed nothing to world history, Guns, Germs and Steel remains as sadly relevant as it was when first published 20 years ago. Jared Diamond's thesis--that some people groups have historically triumphed over others not because they were made up of innately superior human beings, but rather because of the environmental factors that shaped their societies and fostered technological growth--is so simple and seemingly self-apparent that it’s hard to believe anyone ever had to write a book to prove it. And yet, as the examples above demonstrate, someone did--and a loud western minority (majority?) has still not gotten the message. This book won the Pulitzer and looms large in the pop history genre to this day, so I won’t spend too much time discussing its merits or breaking down its case point by point. Diamond argues persuasively and in great detail that, while humans themselves are pretty much the same everywhere, the environments in which our ancestors had to eke out their livings were not. Some parts of the globe (most notably the huge landmass comprising modern Europe, Asia, and North Africa) yielded an abundance of domesticable plant and animal species, along with the climate necessary to take advantage of these, while other regions did not lend themselves to farming in the same way. Agriculture led to food surpluses and sedentary living, which in turn led to denser populations, increased social and political stratification, and more time and resources for non-essential crafts and trades. With proximity to animals and large, concentrated groups of humans also came more diverse and complex diseases, and eventually immunity or resistance to these diseases. Finally, while the Eurasian landmass is oriented on an east-west axis, meaning that crops, animals, and ideas can spread thousands of miles in a short amount of time with no significant change in climate or environment type, the north-south axes of Africa and the Americas (complete with their own vast deserts and rainforests) make such sharing far more difficult. It’s not that so-called "primitive" societies are in any way worse than so-called "advanced" ones (Diamond claims that hunter-gatherers are actually better nourished on average than farmers, and they certainly seem no less happy), but they lack the biological, technological, and political advantages that large, sedentary societies possess. When a society armed with guns, horses, and deadly diseases comes against one without, the resulting conquest has nothing to do with the “genetic superiority” of the victors and everything to do with their material assets. Diamond is a biologist by trade, not a historian or an anthropologist, and he is at his best when describing the scientific principles behind the broad sweep of human history. He tends to falter when dealing with more specific details of history and culture, as when he claims that "Like Arabs and Jews, Koreans and Japanese are peoples joined by blood, yet locked in traditional enmity" (449). (The notion that Jews and Muslims are natural enemies is a popular one in this day and age, but totally unsupported by history; I suspect the relationship between Korea and Japan is more nuanced than he gives it credit for being, too.) Diamond's style can be dry and a bit repetitive, and he gives New Guinea (his adoptive homeland) what seems like a disproportionate amount of attention. There is also a subtle but unpleasant tinge of social Darwinism in his treatment of imperialism: he never attempts to explain why technologically-advanced peoples always seem to prey on their weaker neighbors, only how they do so--the implication being that such conflicts are inevitable whenever there is a power imbalance and that physical prowess is, in itself, justification for conquest. I don't think Diamond is intentionally advocating for the survival of the fittest (that would be at odds with the whole central thrust of his argument), but in a book whose express purpose is to explain why some peoples have come to dominate others, it seems like a pretty major oversight to neglect the motives of the people in question.Nevertheless, Diamond deserves credit for such a comprehensive and lucid treatment of an enormous and multifaceted topic. His arguments are rigorous, he treats his subjects with an even hand and fitting respect, and it's clear that his goal is to empower the oppressed rather than to glorify their oppressors. Recommended to anyone interested in why the world is how it is and unsatisfied with the reductive, self-serving rhetoric of our time and place.

Guns, Germs and Steel deserves two reviews, because writing one cannot do it justice. The first part of my review will be objective, and will concern general readers. The second part of my review will be personal and will deal with how I felt while reading this book. I'm writing this review now, with the details fresh in my mind, having finished the book only moments ago.Guns, Germs and Steel attempts to answer a complex geopolitical question ; Why have the Europeans emerged as the dominant power in the world, while many other native populations died out? Classically, the answer to this question is racist. In this book, Jared Diamond has explained through careful examination and observation why that racist answer should be consigned to oblivion. The question is addressed over 19 chapters, each of them covering as much ground as possible, to give a broad perspective and scope, with scientific studies and research to back up every claim. The argument stands tall on the basis of good science, spruced-up logic and well grounded theories. The average reader will delight in the simplicity of the book, and how the concepts are explained in great detail without excessive jargon. Jared goes over the rise and fall of civilizations, the modern day players, the development of technologies, and every anthropological factor that might possibly hold a clue. He treats this question as a giant puzzle, and gently assembles the pieces together to make the outline of a picture. Moreover, he himself admits that this is merely the outline of the picture, and the gaps need to be filled in by other writers, and more knowledge. That makes the book endearing, because the author understands the scope of the project, and acknowledges his own limitations. The writing style is somewhat verbose, and would benefit from some hack-n-slash editing, but overall, it remains an excellent book for most readers. Part 2.Unfortunately, I'm not one of those readers. Time to rant a bit. WHYY is the book so slow? I understand that he's trying to not be racist, but treading on eggshells all the way through the book, giving multiple explanations and scenarios to justify the same theory becomes taxing. Frustratingly enough, I understand the need to do that. It took one book, Madison's 'Passing of the Races', to inspire a man like Hitler into committing genocide, so this is probably a topic to tread carefully around. That doesn't make the argument style ANY less annoying. The explanations are drawn out and EVERY single detail is highlighted. With a background in Biotechnology and a strong interest in related sciences, I find his overexplanation of the subject terribly draining in many places. Furthermore, there are a few flaws in the argument, which I will discuss once a few other people have finished reading the book, and I've had a solid discussion with them. In simple terms, a normal scientific book will usually explain a concept at the start of the book, and for the rest of the book, will assume that you know the concept, so as to not double back on explanations. Not Mr. Diamond, noooo. I agree that this book should be made mandatory for anyone with a racist temperament, and their intelligence likely requires the repeated explanations but most people don't. I would happily recommend this book to an average person, but I would think ten times before recommending it to any of my friends because they are likely to get bored and abandon it halfway.More discussion on the flaws in theory is yet to come.

Why did Europe succeed?27 December 2012	This is one of those books that tries to ask the question of why the European civilisation managed to succeed where all other world civilisations failed. His conclusions are interesting, however we must remember that even now, fifteen years after this book was completed we are seeing an economic collapse in the west against an economic resurgence in China, India, and Brazil.	One of the ideas that he had was due to the axis of the continents. The only continent on a horizontal axis is the Eurasian mega-continent, which means that the entire continent is located in the temperate zone. However I find that idea to be a little dubious. Okay, granted, major civilisations arose across the continent: Europe, Arabia, India, and China; and trade existed among these four civilisations, however it does not really account for the rise of Europe to the exclusion of the rest.	One interesting idea I would suggest is to do with the Mongol hordes that smashed across Asia and the Middle East. In a way the Middle East never recovered from those invasions, and China was knocked back hundreds of years. Europe, by pure chance, managed to be spared, which meant that they were able to continue to develop ahead of the other Eurasian powers. This also resulted in them developing shipping which enabled them to take control of the Arabian Sea from the Arabs (since the land routes had been subsequently blocked by the Mongols).	The idea of trade along a horizontal axis is interesting, and we note that there was not much trade between the civilisations of America. Even then simple trade is unlikely to be hindered by tropical conditions. One thing about the American tribes is that they never developed shipping, which would have been something that prevented them from trading over long distances. In Africa we don't see much in the way of trade either, and the closer you get to the equator, the less developed the nations you encounter.	The concept of germs is interesting in that disease is a barrier to development. With malaria in the tropics it makes development of civilisation there difficult at best, and this can also prove a hindrance to trade, and Malaria is a disease that does not thrive well in colder climates. We also note that the common cold wrecked havoc in the Americas, where as the only disease we inherited from the New World was chlamydia, which is a sexually transmitted disease (the common cold is airbourne). However, that does not mean that Europe had been spared its devastating diseases, as the black plague ran rampant for over five hundred years and accounted for the death of up to a third of the population at its height.	Guns and steel deal more with technological development. The Eurasian civilisations had steel and guns were imported from China, but some suggest that the Chinese never used gunpower for weapons. That is rubbish. The Chinese had developed and were using explosives and rockets in warfare, but that did not save them from the Mongol Hordes. Even then, guns were a pretty poor weapon up until the eighteenth century, and were still quite inadequate. It wasn't until the 20th century that their truly devastating power comes into play.	The the balkanised nature of the European states also has a part to play. There is a point in that because there are all these competing countries all trying to gain an advantage over the other, which results in a perpetual arms race. That did not happen in China because the Chinese government pretty much controlled the entire region. However, that does not account for the fact that such balkanisation existed in the Americas and Africa. This also existed to an extent in the Middle East and India, but both of these regions, for a long time, have been under the dominant power of a single empire (the Ottomans in the Middle East and the Mogols, and later the British, in India). 	To me, the only real answer to this is that not only was Europe spared the ravaging of the Mongol hordes, but that we Europeans are in reality a sadistic and savage lot who are always looking for faster and more sophisticated ways of killing each other. It is not that the Native Americans lived in peace, they didn't, it was just that they were satisfied with using basic weapons. Even when they did have access to guns, they took them and then turned them on each other.

The title “Guns, Germs and Steel” invokes in one’s mind the image of clacking metals and blazing guns. Then you suddenly realize you forgot about the germs part because you had no idea how to work gooey pathogens into such an awesome visual. In retrospect, however, you feel like Germs should have been the focal point of this title. Upon further musings, you reject that notion too and want to settle for something more mundane like “A brief history of post-Pleistocene humanity”. Maybe a more riveting title would have driven sales in the upward direction, but the central question that this book sets out to answer is no cakewalk: “Why did history take such divergent trajectories in the different continents?” Why indeed?Different variants of the same question have been posed for quite some time: “Why did Africa fail to launch a single civilization in the past 10,000 years or so?” “Of all the landmasses in the world, why did Eurasia enjoy a such massive headstart in creating giant empires, like the Roman empire in Italy or the Shang Dynasty in China?” “Why did Australian aborigines fail to move beyond the stone age on a timescale of thousands of years whereas the Europeans succeeded in creating and sustaining a modern nation state within two centuries of landing on the western coast of the continent?”Many answers have been proposed and depending on your worldview, you may prefer one over several others. In the pre-Renaissance era, the view of most people pondering over such matters can be summarized in a simple sentence: “They are filthy savages, we are civilized humans. That’s it” With the advent of biological evolution, efforts were made to recast the answer in more scientific terms: “Just as the Cro-Magnons were an evolutionary upgrade on the Neanderthals, so are we (Europeans/ Caucasians) a more advanced form of humans vis-à-vis the blacks/aborigines/Indians.” In retrospect, it might sound hilarious, but at that time, serious research works were carried out to show that Africans have a more primitive skull structure akin to the Chimpanzees. And then came Mendel with genetics and it did not take much time for people to weaponize that concept either. The Nazis believed they were a genetically superior race and actively carried out eugenics to optimize favorable hereditary characteristics among their people, despite zero science to back up such a genocidal social policy. To this day, the genetic superiority theory has no shortage of preachers and evangelists. The likes of Sam Harris and Jordan Petersen are going around the globe and brandishing psychologist Charles Murray’s Race-and-Intelligence Bell Curve. The implication is pretty straightforward, “Look mate, even if slavery, segregation, Jim Crow, mass incarceration and the likes did not happen, the African Americans would still be hard-pressed to climb up the social ladder since they are genetically indisposed to do so. Sad!!” The appropriation of scientific concepts by intellectuals of the social science disciplines to justify confounding claims is nothing new. And as I have already stated, each individual would be amenable to a different answer to this question depending on how he/she perceives the world-at-large. So, in the marketplace of ideas, who should we subscribe to? In other words, which discipline or branch of science is best-suited to answer this question? And the answer is: Anthropology. Wild as it may seem at first, you would think the responsibility to answer a question regarding humans should befell the people whose job is to literally study humans.And this is where this book shines brightly. Jared Diamond does a fantastic job of breaking down the geographical, agricultural, political and social forces that propelled different people to very disparate directions. But most importantly, this book stands as a solid buttress to human capital. Given the right tools and right conditions of existence, anyone possesses the mental faculty to do anything they would want to do. No one is genetically incapacitated to be an engineer or a physicist. But if you choose to believe otherwise, that is your prerogative. Just read the book and see if it can challenge, if not alter radically, your worldview.

To a certain extent, I've always wondered why Guns, Germs, and Steel caused such a huge splash. The main premise boils down to 'differences in geography cause differences in societies and their history', which belongs to the club of the blindingly obvious.Of course, the real point of the book is to pin down just which differences are the important ones. This is a cause for much arguement, but Diamond has successfully pulled out the most important ones as applied to history as a whole. This largely turns into a study of what plants and animals were successfully domesticated in early prehistory, and how that turned certain areas into the origin of settled agriculture. That is still fairly basic stuff, but benefits greatly from studying the results from all around the world all at once, and examining just what it takes for something to be capable of being domesticated. (I know there's been some interesting work done on that since this book came out, but I haven't seen it escape scholarly journals in more detail than a National Geographic article.)From there, Diamond points out how plants and animals are generally adapted to a certain climate, and that while it is fairly easy to find different climates going east and west (due to cold mountains, dry deserts, wet coasts, and other accidents of geology), large differences of climate are guaranteed when traveling any real distance north and south. Looking at a map and noting that the Americas and Africa are divided into north-south zones, while Eurasia is oriented east-west, then provides material to show why certain areas needed to work everything out independently, while others were able to borrow everything they needed from elsewhere (before the Age of Exploration, the two situations were probably somewhat even by landmass; the book naturally spends much more time looking at the former).The main thing that makes this book new is actually the 'germs' part of the book. It is only fairly recently that we've really become aware of where most of the deadly diseases we have to deal with come from—other animals. So societies that have and live closely with lots of domesticatible animals get to suffer from deadly epidemics when an occasional virus adapts to a new host (us), and then develop some level of immunity to it. When people who don't have much/anything in the way of domesticated animals run into people who do, they die off as multiple epidemics run through the countryside. This is the other 'new' part—the fact that a lot of Native American population was wiped out by disease is well known, but it's been hard to realize the scale of the disaster. The "Mound Builders" were a disappeared pre-Columbian civilization of the Mississippi valley, and only recently has it been realized it was actually wiped out by European diseases before any Europeans got there to see it.The 'guns' and 'steel' parts of the book are essentially non-existent. They just serve as part of the proximate cause of how Europeans came to dominate the world before turning to look for the ultimate causes back in prehistory. This is where his biases as a biologist who's picked up a fair amount of practical cultural anthropology show. While he does discuss technology, and the fact that the wider the range of where you can get ideas from, the more ideas you will be able to encounter, he doesn't spend any time looking at the basics of physical technology. A basic study of easily available copper, tin, iron, and clay deposits, compared with the areas that were able to develop settled agriculture could explain much that remains mysterious to him.It's decidedly a layman's book, and has the advantage of being aware of more current research than any pre-college textbook. The fairly breezy, non-technical writing is set off by a good number of informative charts and maps and allow him to make his points without miring himself in the minutia that would lose the non-dedicated reader. Just being able to tackle most of pre-history in a single reasonably-sized volume is an impressive feat of summarization, and the most impressive thing about the book.

I'll let David Graeber speak of this book in a small blurb he wrote about Abdullah Öcalan's "Manifesto For a Democratic Civilization I: The Age of Masked Gods and Disguised Kings":"Considering the circumstances under which the book was written, I'd say the achievement here is quite impressive. Abdullah Ocalan seems to have done a better job writing with the extremely limited resources allowed him by his jailers than authors like Francis Fukuyama or Jared Diamond did with access to the world's finest research libraries." — David GraeberThe conditions of which David Graeber speaks are that of being locked up in solitary confinement with 24 hour/day artificial light illuminating his cell. Allowed to have one book at a time, and oftimes no writing instruments. And the book(s) he wrote were communicated to the public via live speach, or in first draft form written hastily as part of his testimony for his trials.So, is Jared Diamond's book that bad that a guy who's locked up in such brutal conditions can do better? Well, not really. It is almost certain that Jared Diamond reveals important factors that went into the emergence and differentiation of variagrated civilization, it's just that his analysis is definitely incomplete by simple virtue of being more materialistic than that of any hardline marxist. There is very few, and ultimately unconvincing, arguments about the formation of institutions, the emergence of cities, and ultimately of nation-states. And almost no mention of any social movement of any kind.True to the title, the red thread woven through the entire analysis of civilization is done by looking at why certain societies had developed guns, germs, and steel the way they have. It presents rather novel ideas for the layperson not versed in the subject. A quick, and woefully incomplete, enumeration being:1) Euroasia had a geographical advantage because it had more indigenous crops that could potentially be domesticated2) The domestication of said plants could spread from the Fertile Crescent where they first emerged more easily because of relatively uniform climate along the longer axis (east-west) of Eurasia. The Americas suffering from the fact that their longest geographical distance was from north-south, thus cross-cutting through extremely different climates3) Eurasia also had more potential animals for domestication (also goes into why some species are better suited than others), thus Eurasians had a very decisive advantage in terms of the diseases that they developed resistance too, since most ones are of animal origin And so on. You get the picture, right? Fairly solid arguments, and worth carefully studying because they can almost immediately shut up racists, euro-centrists, and so on. But do not think that by reading this book you have garnered enough information about early human history to call it quits. It might be enough to show off at certain parties, but in order to actually synthesise new ways forward there's a long list of problems, not even touched upon, by Jared Diamond.
